yoruba: A dẹ̀ rí ìyẹn nínú ìgbẹ̀jọ́ọ Rana Ayyub.

english: She was told, "Come on, you're making such a big deal about this.
yoruba: Wọ́n sọ fún-un pé, "Wá, ó ń sọ ǹkan yìí di bàbàrà.

english: It's boys being boys.
yoruba: Àwọn ọmọkùnrin ni wọ́n ń ṣìṣe ọmọkùnrin.

english: And so we need to pair new legislation with efforts at training.
yoruba: A nílò láti ṣe àsopọ̀ òfin tuntun pẹ̀lú ìgbìyànjú ìfikọ́ra.

english: And education has to be aimed on the media as well.
yoruba: A gbọ́dọ̀ dojú ètò-ẹ̀kọ́ kọ àwọn ilé-iṣẹ́ ìròyìn bákan náà.

english: Journalists need educating about the phenomenon of deepfakes so they don't amplify and spread them.
yoruba: Àwọn akọ̀ròyìn náà nílò ẹ̀kọ́ nípa ìlàna fọ́rán ayédèrú kí wọ́n má baà pariwo rẹ̀ kọ́ sì má fọnká.

english: And this is the part where we're all involved.
yoruba: Ibí yìí ni ó ti kan gbogbo wa.

english: Each and every one of us needs educating.
yoruba: Ẹnìkànkan nínú wa nílò kíkọ́.

english: We click, we share, we like, and we don't even think about it.
yoruba: A máa ń tẹ̀, a máa ń ṣe àtagbà, a máa ń fẹ́ràn, a ò dẹ̀ kín ronú nípa rẹ̀.

english: We need to do better.
yoruba: A nílò láti ṣe ju báyìí lọ.

english: We need far better radar for fakery.
yoruba: A nílò irinṣẹ́ aṣàwárí gidi fún ayédèrú.

english: So as we're working through these solutions, there's going to be a lot of suffering to go around.
yoruba: À ń ṣiṣẹ́ lóri àwọn ọ̀nà-àbáyọ wọ̀nyí, ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ ìyà ni yóó wà tí yóò sì kárí.

english: Rana Ayyub is still wrestling with the fallout.
yoruba: Ranna Ayyub ṣì ń jíjà gùdù pẹ̀lú ìpadàbọ rẹ̀.

english: She still doesn't feel free to express herself on- and offline.
yoruba: Ara rẹ̀ ò tíì balẹ̀ láti sọ̀rọ̀ lórí àti kúrò lórí ẹrọ ayélukára.

english: And as she told me, she still feels like there are thousands of eyes on her naked body, even though, intellectually, she knows it wasn't her body.
yoruba: Bó ṣe sọ fún mi, ó sì ń dàbì ẹni pé ẹgbẹ̀run ojú ló ń wo ìhòhò òun, bó tilẹ̀ jẹ́ wí pé, nínu ọpọ̀lọ, ó mọ̀ wí pé ara òun kọ́.

english: And she has frequent panic attacks, especially when someone she doesn't know tries to take her picture.
yoruba: Ó máa ń ní ìbẹ̀rù lemọ́lemọ́, pàápàá jùlọ tí ẹnìkan tí kò mọ̀ rí bá gbìyànjú láti ya àwòran rẹ̀.

english: What if they're going to make another deepfake? she thinks to herself.
yoruba: "Tó bá jẹ́ wí pé wọ́n fẹ́ ṣe fọ́rán ayédèrú míràn ńkọ́? " ó máa ń ròó lọ́kan ara rẹ̀.

english: And so for the sake of individuals like Rana Ayyub and the sake of our democracy, we need to do something right now.
yoruba: Fún ànfàní àwọn ènìyàn bi Rana Ayyub àti fún ànfàní ìjọba àwarawa, a nílò láti ṣe ǹkan nísinyìí.

english: Thank you.
yoruba: Ẹ ṣeun.

english: What tech companies know about your kids
yoruba: Ǹkan tí àwọn ilé-iṣẹ́ ìmọ̀-ẹ̀rọ mọ̀ nípa àwọn ọmọọ̀ yín.

english: Every day, every week, we agree to terms and conditions.
yoruba: Lójoojúmọ́, lọ́sọ̀ọ̀sẹ̀, a máa ń gba àwọn àdéhùn àti àsọtẹ́lẹ̀.

english: And when we do this, we provide companies with the lawful right to do whatever they want with our data and with the data of our children.
yoruba: Tí a bá sì ṣe èyí, à ń fún àwọn ilé-iṣẹ́ ní ẹ̀tọ́ lábẹ́ òfin láti ṣe ohun-kóhun tó bá wùn wọ́n pẹ̀lu dátà wa àti dátà àwọn ọmọ wa.

english: Which makes us wonder: how much data are we giving away of children, and what are its implications?
yoruba: Tó máa ń jẹ́ ká bèrè: dátà ni à ń fi sílẹ̀ nípa àwọn ọmọ wa, kí dè ni ìpadàbọ rẹ̀?

english: I'm an anthropologist, and I'm also the mother of two little girls.
yoruba: Onímọ̀ nípa àjọṣepọ̀ ènìyàn láwùjọ ni mí, mo dẹ̀ tún jẹ ìyá àwọn ọmọdébìnrin méjì.

english: And I started to become interested in this question in 2015 when I suddenly realized that there were vast -- almost unimaginable amounts of data traces that are being produced and collected about children.
yoruba: Mo bẹ̀rẹ̀ sí nífẹ̀ nínu ìbéérè yìí ní ọdún 2015 nígbà tí mo mọ̀ pé ọ̀pọ̀ -- ní iye ìtọpa dátà tí ènìyàn ò lérò tí wọ́n ń pèsè tí wọ́n sì ńgbà nípa àwọn ọmọ.

english: So I launched a research project, which is called Child Data Citizen, and I aimed at filling in the blank.
yoruba: Mo bẹ̀rẹ̀ àkànṣe iṣẹ́-ìwádìí, tí wọ́n ń pè ní Dáta Omọ onílù, mo sì pinnu láti dí àlàfo náà.

english: Now you may think that I'm here to blame you for posting photos of your children on social media, but that's not really the point.
yoruba: Ní báyìí ẹ lè máa rò ó wí pé mo wá síbí láti dáa yín lẹ́bi fún fífi àwòrán àwọn ọmọ yín sórí ìkàni ayélukára, ṣùgbọ́n kókó ọ̀rọ̀ ibẹ̀ kọ́ nìyẹn.

english: The problem is way bigger than so-called "sharenting.
yoruba: Wàhálà yìí tóbi ju ǹkan tí wọ́n ń pè ní "fífi àwòran ọmọ sórí ìkàni ayélukára lọ.

english: This is about systems, not individuals.
yoruba: Èyí jẹ́ nípa ètò, kìí ṣe àwọn ènìyàn.

english: You and your habits are not to blame.
yoruba: Ìwọ àti ìwà rẹ ò lẹ́bi.

english: For the very first time in history, we are tracking the individual data of children from long before they're born -- sometimes from the moment of conception, and then throughout their lives.
yoruba: Fún ìgbà àkọ́kọ́ nínú ìtàn, à ń tọpa dátà ọmọ kaǹkan láti ìgbà pípẹ́ ká tó bíwọn -- nígbà mìíràn láti ìgbà tí wọ́n bá ti lóyún wọn, àti ní gbogbo ìgbésí ayé wọn.

english: You see, when parents decide to conceive, they go online to look for "ways to get pregnant," or they download ovulation-tracking apps.
yoruba: Ṣé ẹ rí i, tí àwọn òbí bá pinnu láti lóyún, wọ́n máa lọ sórí ẹ̀rọ ayélukára láti wá "ọ̀nà tí a lè gbà lóyún," tàbí kí wọ́n gba àwọn irinṣẹ́ atọpa-ìrọyin.

english: And then, when the baby is born, they track every nap, every feed, every life event on different technologies.
yoruba: Nígbà náà, tí wọ́n bá bí ọmọ náà, wọ́n máa ń tọpa gbogbo oorun, gbogbo ìjẹun, gbogbo ìṣẹ̀lẹ ojú ayé lóri oríṣiríṣi ẹ̀rọ.

english: And all of these technologies transform the baby's most intimate behavioral and health data into profit by sharing it with others.
yoruba: Gbogbo àwọn èrọ wọ̀nyí máa ń ṣe àyídà ìwà ìkọ̀kọ ọmọ àti dátà ìlera rẹ̀ sí èrè pẹ̀lu ṣíṣe àtagbà rẹ̀ pẹ̀lú àwọn mìíràn.

english: So to give you an idea of how this works, in 2019, the British Medical Journal published research that showed that out of 24 mobile health apps, 19 shared information with third parties.
yoruba: Láti fún yín ní òye bí èyí ṣe ń ṣiṣé, ní ọdún 2019, Jọ́nà Ìṣègun orílẹ̀-ède British ṣe àtẹ̀jáde ìwádì tó fi hàn pé nínu irinṣẹ́ ìlera lórí ẹ̀rọ-ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ alágbèká mẹ́rìn-lé-lógún, mọ́kàn-dín-lógún máa ń ṣe àtagbà afitóni pẹ̀lú ẹnìkẹ́ta.

english: And these third parties shared information with 216 other organizations.
yoruba: Àwọn ẹnìkẹ́ta wọ̀nyí máa ṣe àtagbà ìfitónilétí náà pẹ̀lu ilé-iṣẹ́ mẹ́rìn-dín-lókóò-le-nigba mìíràn.

english: Of these 216 other fourth parties, only three belonged to the health sector.
yoruba: Nínu mẹ́rìn-dín-lókóò-le-nigba ẹnìkẹ́rin wọ̀nyí, mẹ́ta péré ni wọ́n jẹ́ ti ẹ̀ka ìlera.

english: The other companies that had access to that data were big tech companies like Google, Facebook or Oracle, they were digital advertising companies and there was also a consumer credit reporting agency.
yoruba: Àwọn ilé-iṣẹ́ mìíràn tí wọ́n ní ànfàní sí dátà yẹn ni àwọn ilé-iṣẹ́ ìmọ̀-ẹ̀rọ ńlá bíi Google, Facebook tàbí Oracle, ilé-iṣẹ́ tí wọ́n ń ṣe ìpolówó ọjà dígítà niwọ́n bẹ́ẹ̀ sì ni àwọn àjọ tí wọ́n ń jábọ̀ ẹ̀yáwó oníbárà náà wà.

english: So you get it right: ad companies and credit agencies may already have data points on little babies.
yoruba: Nítorí náà ẹ gbà á: àwọn ilé-iṣẹ́ ìpolówó àti àwọn àjọ ayánilówó lè ti ni ààye dáta nípa àwọn ìkókó tẹ́lẹ̀.

english: But mobile apps, web searches and social media are really just the tip of the iceberg, because children are being tracked by multiple technologies in their everyday lives.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n kékeré lásán ni irínṣẹ́ orí ẹ̀rọ-ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ alágbèká, wíwá ǹkan lóri ìtàkùn àgbáyé àti ìkànì ìbánidọ́rẹ̀, nítorí wọ́n ń tọpa àwọn ọmọdé lórí ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ ìmọ̀-ẹ̀rọ lójojúmọ́ ayé wọn.

english: They're tracked by home technologies and virtual assistants in their homes.
yoruba: Wọ́n ń tọpa wọn pẹ̀lú àwọn ẹ̀rọ inú ilé àti àwọn ẹ̀rọ arannilọ́wọ́ nínu ilé wọn.

english: They're tracked by educational platforms and educational technologies in their schools.
yoruba: Wọ́n ń tọpa wọn pẹ̀lú àwọn ìkànì ètò-ẹ̀kọ́ àti àwọn ìmọ̀-ẹ̀rọ ètò-ẹ̀kọ́ ní ilé-ẹ̀kọ wọn.

english: They're tracked by online records and online portals at their doctor's office.
yoruba: Wọ́n ń tọpa wọn pẹ̀lú àwọn àkọsílẹ lórí ìkọ̀nì ayélukára àti àwọn ẹ̀ka orí ẹ̀rọ ayélukára ní ọ́fíísì oníṣégùn-òyìnbo wọn.

english: They're tracked by their internet-connected toys, their online games and many, many, many, many other technologies.
yoruba: Wọ́n ń tọpa wọn pẹ̀lú àwọn ǹkan-ìṣeré wọn tí wọ́n sopọ̀ pẹ̀lu ìkàni ayélukára, àwọn ayò orí ẹ̀rọ ayélukára, àti àwọn ẹ̀rọ tó pọ̀ púpọ̀ mìíràn.

english: So during my research, a lot of parents came up to me and they were like, "So what?
yoruba: Lásíkò ìwádìí mi, ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ àwọn òbí ni wọ́n wá bámi wọ́n sì ń sọ pé, "kí wá ni?

english: Why does it matter if my children are being tracked?
yoruba: Kí ló jẹ́ pàtàkì tí wọ́n bá ń tọpa àwọn ọmọ mi?

english: We've got nothing to hide.
yoruba: A ò ní ǹkankan láti fi pamọ́.

english: Well, it matters.
yoruba: Ó dáa, Ó ṣe pàtàkì.

english: It matters because today individuals are not only being tracked, they're also being profiled on the basis of their data traces.
yoruba: Ó ṣe pàtàkì nítorí kìí ṣe pé wọ́n ń tọpa àwọn enìyàn èní nìkan, wọ́n ń ṣe àkọsílẹ̀ wọn pẹ̀lú ìtọpa dátà wọn.

english: Artificial intelligence and predictive analytics are being used to harness as much data as possible of an individual life from different sources: family history, purchasing habits, social media comments.
yoruba: Ìmọ̀ àtọwọ́dá àti ìyànàná àsọtẹ́lẹ̀ ti wọ́n ń lò láti kó dátà tó pọ̀ jọ nípa ìgbésíayé ènìyàn láti oríṣiríṣi orísun: ìtan ẹbí, bárakú ọjà rírà, àríwísí lórí ìkàni ayélukára.

english: And then they bring this data together to make data-driven decisions about the individual.
yoruba: Wọ́n sì ń kó gbogbo dátà yìí jọ láti ṣe ìpinnu ìtọ́ni-dátà nípa ènìyàn.

english: And these technologies are used everywhere.
yoruba: Àwọn ìmọ̀-ẹ̀rọ wọ̀nyí ni wọ́n ń lò níbi gbogbo.

english: Banks use them to decide loans.
yoruba: Ilé-ìfowópamọ́ ń lò wọ́n láti ṣe ìpinnu ẹ̀yáwó.

english: Insurance uses them to decide premiums.
yoruba: Àwọn adójútófò ń lò wọ́n láti ṣe ìpinnu owó ìdójútófò.

english: Recruiters and employers use them to decide whether one is a good fit for a job or not.
yoruba: Àwọn tó ń gbá òṣìṣẹ́ àti àwọn tó ń gba ènìyàn sísẹ́ máa ń lò wọ́n láti ṣe ìpinnu bóyá ènìyán tọ́ fún ìṣẹ́ kan tàbí bẹ́è kọ́.

english: Also the police and courts use them to determine whether one is a potential criminal or is likely to recommit a crime.
yoruba: Bákan náà àwọn ọlọ́pà àti ilé-ẹjọ́ máa ń lò wọ́n láti mọ̀ bóyá ó ṣe é ṣe kí ènìyán hu ìwà ọ̀daràn tàbí ó ṣe é ṣe kí ènìyán tún ìwà ọ̀daran hù.

english: We have no knowledge or control over the ways in which those who buy, sell and process our data are profiling us and our children.
yoruba: A ò nímọ̀ kankan tàbí àkóso lórí ọ̀nà tí àwọn tó ń rà, tà tí wọ́n sì ń lo dátà wa ṣe ń ṣe àkọsílẹ̀ wa àti àwọn ọmọ wa.

english: But these profiles can come to impact our rights in significant ways.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n àwọn àkọsílẹ̀ yìí lè nípa lórí ẹ̀tọ wa ní àwọn ọ̀nà tó ṣe pàtàkì.

english: To give you an example, in 2018 the "New York Times" published the news that the data that had been gathered through online college-planning services -- that are actually completed by millions of high school kids across the US who are looking for a college program or a scholarship -- had been sold to educational data brokers.
yoruba: Láti fún yín ní àpẹẹrẹ, ní ọdún 2018 "New York Times" ṣe àtẹ̀jáde ìròyìn pé àwọn dátà tí wọ́n ti kójọ nípasẹ̀ ìfètòsí ilé-ẹ̀kọ́ gíga lórí ìkàni ayélukára -- tí mílíọ́nù àwọn ọmọ ilé-ẹ̀kọ́ gíga yíká orílẹ̀-ède US tí wọ́n ń wá ètò ẹ̀kọ́ tàbí ẹ̀kọ́-ọ̀fẹ́ fi sílẹ̀ -- ni wọ́n ti tà fún àwọn oníṣówo dátà.

english: Now, researchers at Fordham who studied educational data brokers revealed that these companies profiled kids as young as two on the basis of different categories: ethnicity, religion, affluence, social awkwardness and many other random categories.
yoruba: Ní báyìí, àwọn oníwádìí ni Fordham tí wọ́n ṣèwádìí nípa ìṣòwo dátà fi hàn wí pé àwọn ilé-iṣẹ́ wọ̀nyí máa ń ṣe àkọsílẹ̀ nípa àwọn ọmọdé láti bí ọdún méjì ní oríṣiríṣi ìsọ̀rí: ẹ̀yà, ẹ̀sìn, ọrọ̀, ìwà-ìbàjẹ́ láwùjọ àti àwọn ìsọ̀rí àdijúmú mìíràn.

english: And then they sell these profiles together with the name of the kid, their home address and the contact details to different companies, including trade and career institutions, student loans and student credit card companies.
yoruba: Wọ́n sì ń ta àwọn àkọsílẹ̀ wọ̀nyí pẹ̀lú orúkọ ọmọ náà, àdírẹ́si ilée wọn àti àwọn ọ̀nà ìkànsíra-ẹni fún oríṣiríṣi ilé-iṣẹ́, pẹ̀lú àwọn ilé-iṣẹ́ òwò àti iṣẹ́-ìṣe, àwọn ilé-iṣẹ́ owó-ẹ̀yá fún akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ àti ike ìgbawó àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́.

english: To push the boundaries, the researchers at Fordham asked an educational data broker to provide them with a list of 14-to-15-year-old girls who were interested in family planning services.
yoruba: Láti kọjá ẹnu àlà, àwọn oníwádìí ní Fordham sọ fún oníṣòwo dátà ẹ̀kọ́ kan pé kó pèsè àkọ́jọpọ̀ àwọn ọmọbìnrin lábẹ́ ọdún mẹ́rìnlá sí mẹ́ẹ̀dógún tí wọ́n nífẹ̀ẹ́ síìfètòsẹ́bí fún wọn.

english: The data broker agreed to provide them the list.
yoruba: Oníṣòwo dátà náà sì gbà láti pèse àkójọpọ̀ náà fún wọn.

english: So imagine how intimate and how intrusive that is for our kids.
yoruba: Ẹ ronú sí irú àṣírí àti àyanjúràn tí èyí jẹ́ fún àwọn ọmọ wa.

english: But educational data brokers are really just an example.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n àpẹẹrẹ lásán ni àwọn oníṣòwo dátà ẹ̀kọ́ jẹ́.

english: The truth is that our children are being profiled in ways that we cannot control but that can significantly impact their chances in life.
yoruba: Ọ̀títọ́ ibẹ̀ ni wí pé wọ́n ń ṣe àkọsílẹ̀ àwọn ọmọ wa ní ọ̀nà tí a ò lè darí rẹ̀ ṣùgbọ́n tí ó lẹ̀ ní ipa pàtàkì lára ànfàni wọn nílé ayé.

english: So we need to ask ourselves: can we trust these technologies when it comes to profiling our children?
yoruba: A nílò láti birawa: ǹjẹ́ a lè fọkàn tán àwọn ìmọ̀-ẹ̀rọ wọ̀nyí tó bá kan àkọsílẹ̀ àwọn ọmọ wa?

english: Can we?
yoruba: Ǹjẹ́ a lè ṣe bẹ́ẹ̀?

english: My answer is no.
yoruba: Ìdáhùn mi ni rárá.

english: As an anthropologist, I believe that artificial intelligence and predictive analytics can be great to predict the course of a disease or to fight climate change.
yoruba: Gẹ́gẹ́ bi onímọ̀ nípa àjọṣepọ̀ ènìyàn láwùjọ, mo nígbàgbọ́ wí pé ìmọ̀-àtọwọ́dá àti ìyànàná àsọtẹ́lẹ̀ lè dára lóòtó láti sọ àsọtẹ́lẹ̀ okùnfa ààrùn kan tàbí láti gbógun ti àyípadà ojú-ọjọ́.

english: But we need to abandon the belief that these technologies can objectively profile humans and that we can rely on them to make data-driven decisions about individual lives.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n a nílò láti ṣe àgbétì ìgbàgbọ́ wí pé àwọn ìmọ̀-ẹ̀rọ wọ̀nyí lè ṣe àkọsílẹ̀ àwọn ènìyàn láìṣẹ̀gbè àti wí pé a lè gbára léwọn láti fún wa ní ìpinnu nípasẹ̀ dátà nípa ìgbésíayé ènìyàn.

english: Because they can't profile humans.
yoruba: Nítorí wọn ò lè ṣe àkọsílẹ̀ àwọn ènìyàn.

english: Data traces are not the mirror of who we are.
yoruba: Ìtọpa dátà ò kí ń ṣe àwòran irú ènìyàn tí à ń ṣe.

english: Humans think one thing and say the opposite, feel one way and act differently.
yoruba: Àwọn ènìyàn máa ń ro ǹkan kan kí wọ́n sì sọ ìdàkejì rẹ̀, á ṣewọ́n bákan wọn ó sì hu ìwà míràn.

english: Algorithmic predictions or our digital practices cannot account for the unpredictability and complexity of human experience.
yoruba: Àwọn àsọtẹ́lẹ̀ ètò tàbí àwọn àṣa dígítà ò lè jíyìn fún àìlèsọ-àsọtẹ́lẹ̀ àti àmúdijú ìrírí ọmọ ènìyàn.

english: But on top of that, these technologies are always -- always -- in one way or another, biased.
yoruba: Ṣugbọ́n lórí ìyẹn, àwọn ìmọ̀-ẹ̀rọ wọ̀nyí máa ń ṣègbè -- ní gbogbo ìgbà -- lọ́nà kan tàbí kejì.

english: You see, algorithms are by definition sets of rules or steps that have been designed to achieve a specific result, OK?
yoruba: Ṣe ẹ rí i, àwọn èto pẹ̀lú oríkì ni àkójọpọ̀ àwọn òfin tàbí ìgbésẹ̀ tí wọ́n ti ṣẹ̀da rẹ̀ láti mú èsì kan pàtó, ṣó yé?

english: But these sets of rules or steps cannot be objective, because they've been designed by human beings within a specific cultural context and are shaped by specific cultural values.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n àwọn àkójọpọ̀ òfin wọ̀nyí ò lè jẹ́ òótọ́, nítorí àwọn ènìyàn ni wọ́n ṣèda wọn láàrín ọ̀gangan ipò àṣà kan ní pàtó wọ́n sì mọ

english: So when machines learn, they learn from biased algorithms, and they often learn from biased databases as well.
yoruba: Nígbà tí àwọn ẹ̀rọ bá ń kẹ́kọ̀ọ́, wọ́n máa ń kẹ́kọ̀ọ́ pẹ̀lu ètò aṣègbè, wọ́n sì máa ń kẹ́kọ̀ọ́ látara àkójọpọ̀ dátà aṣègbè.

english: At the moment, we're seeing the first examples of algorithmic bias.
yoruba: Lọ́wọ́lọ́wọ́ yìí, à ń rí àwọn àpẹẹrẹ ètò aṣègbè àkọ́kọ́.

english: And some of these examples are frankly terrifying.
yoruba: Díẹ̀ nínú àwọn àpẹrẹ wọ̀nyí ń dẹ́rù bani.

english: This year, the AI Now Institute in New York published a report that revealed that the AI technologies that are being used for predictive policing have been trained on "dirty" data.
yoruba: Ní ọdún yìí, ilé-ìwe AI Now ní New York tí ṣe àtẹ̀jáde ìjábọ̀ kan tó fi hàn wí pé ìmọ̀-ẹ̀rọ AI tí wọ́n ń lò fún àsọtẹ́lẹ̀ ọlọ́pà ní wọ́n kọ́ pẹ̀lú dátà "onídọ̀tí".

english: This is basically data that had been gathered during historical periods of known racial bias and nontransparent police practices.
yoruba: Èyí jẹ́ dátà tí wọ́n ti gbà lásíkò ìtàn tí a mọ̀ fún ìṣegbè ẹlẹ́yámẹ̀yà àti àwọn ìṣesí ọlọ́pà tí ò fojú hàn.

english: Because these technologies are being trained with dirty data, they're not objective, and their outcomes are only amplifying and perpetrating police bias and error.
yoruba: Nítorí dátà tó dọ̀tí ni wọ́n fi kọ́ àwọn ìmọ̀-ẹ̀rọ wọ̀nyí, wọn ò sọ tòótọ́, àbájáde wọn kò ń ṣàfikún àti àtúnṣe ìṣègbe ọlọ́pà àti àṣìṣe.

english: So I think we are faced with a fundamental problem in our society.
yoruba: Mo rò wí pé ìṣòro gidi ni à ń kojú ní àwùjọ wa.

english: We are starting to trust technologies when it comes to profiling human beings.
yoruba: A ti bẹ̀rẹ̀ sí gba àwọn ìmọ̀-ẹ̀rọ gbọ́ tó bá kan kí á ṣe àkọsílẹ̀ nípa àwọn ọmọ ènìyàn.

english: We know that in profiling humans, these technologies are always going to be biased and are never really going to be accurate.
yoruba: A mọ̀ wí pé láti ṣe àkọsílẹ̀ nípa àwọn ọmọ ènìyàn, àwọn ìmọ̀-ẹ̀rọ wọ̀nyí máa ṣègbè ní gbogbo ìgbà wọn ò sì ní péye tó bẹ́ẹ̀.

english: So what we need now is actually political solution.
yoruba: Ǹkan tí a nìlò báyìí ni ọ̀nà-àbáyọ òṣèlú.

english: We need governments to recognize that our data rights are our human rights.
yoruba: A fẹ́ kí ìjọba mọ̀ wí pé ẹ̀tọ ọmọ ènìyan wa ni ẹ̀to dátà wa.

english: (Applause and cheers)
yoruba: (àtẹ́wọ́ àti ariwo).

english: Until this happens, we cannot hope for a more just future.
yoruba: Àyàfi tí èyí bá ṣẹlẹ̀, a ò lè nírèti ọjọ́-iwájú adọ́gba.

english: I worry that my daughters are going to be exposed to all sorts of algorithmic discrimination and error.
yoruba: Mò ń ronú wí pé àwọn ọmọbìnrin mi máa kojú onírúúrú ètò ẹlẹ́yàmẹ̀yà àti àṣìṣe.

english: You see the difference between me and my daughters is that there's no public record out there of my childhood.
yoruba: Ṣé ẹ rí ìyàtọ̀ tó wà láàrín èmi àti àwọn ọmọbìrin mi ni wí pé kò sí àkọsílẹ̀ ìjọba níta níbẹ̀yẹn nípa ìgbà-èwe mi.

english: There's certainly no database of all the stupid things that I've done and thought when I was a teenager.
yoruba: Dájúdájú Kò sí àkójọpọ̀ dáta nípa gbogbo ǹkan ìbàjẹ́ tí mo ti ṣe tí mo ti rò nígbà tí mo wà lábẹ́ ogún ọdún.

english: But for my daughters this may be different.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n fún àwọn ọmọbìnrin mi èyí lè yàtọ̀.

english: The data that is being collected from them today may be used to judge them in the future and can come to prevent their hopes and dreams.
yoruba: Dátà tí wọ́n ń gbà lọ́wọ́ wọn lónì lè di lílò láti ṣe ìdájọ́ wọn lọ́jọ́ iwájú ó dẹ̀ lè dèna ìrètí àti àlá wọn.

english: I think that's it's time.
yoruba: Mo rò wí pé àsìkó ti tó.

english: It's time that we all step up.
yoruba: Àsìkó ti tó fúnwa láti tẹ̀síwájú.

english: It's time that we start working together as individuals, as organizations and as institutions, and that we demand greater data justice for us and for our children before it's too late.
yoruba: Àsìkó ti tó láti bẹ̀rẹ̀ sí ṣiṣẹ́ pọ̀ gẹ́gẹ́ bi ẹnìyàn, gẹ́gẹ́ bí àjọ àti ilé-iṣẹ́, ká sì bèèrè fún ìdájọ́ dátà tó tóbi fún àwa àti àwọn ọmọ wakó tó pẹ́jù.

english: Thank you.
yoruba: Ẹ ṣeun.

english: Facebook's role in Brexit - and the threat to democracy.
yoruba: Ipa Facebook nínú Brexit – àti ìdẹ́rùbà rẹ̀ sí ìjọba àwarawa.

english: So, on the day after the Brexit vote, in June 2016, when Britain woke up to the shock of discovering that we're leaving the European Union, my editor at the "Observer" newspaper in the UK asked me to go back to South Wales, where I grew up, and to write a report.
yoruba: Nítorí náà, ní ọjọ́ kejì lẹ́yìn ìbo Brexit, ní oṣù Òkúdù ọdún 2016, nígbà tí orílẹ̀-ède Brítain jí sí ìjayà mímọ̀ wí pé à ń kúrò Àjọ-Ìgbìmọ Ilẹ̀-Europe sílẹ̀, olóòtú mi ní ìwé-ìròyin “Observer” ní orílẹ̀-ède UK sọ fún mi wí pé kí n padà sí South Wales, níbi tí mo ti ṣe kékeré, kí n sì kọ ìjábọ̀.

english: And so I went to a town called Ebbw Vale.
yoruba: Mo bá lọ sí ìlú kan tí wọ́n ń pè ní Ebbw Vale.

english: Here it is.
yoruba: Òun rè é.

english: It's in the South Wales Valleys, which is this quite special place.
yoruba: Ó wà ní South Wales Valleys, t’ó jẹ́ ibi àkànṣe tí ó pa lọ́wọ́ báyìí.

english: So it's had this very, sort of rich, working-class culture, and it's famous for its Welsh male voice choirs and rugby and its coal.
yoruba: Nítorí náà ó ti ní àṣà ọ̀wọ́-òṣìṣẹ́, ibi ọrọ̀, ó sì gbajúmọ̀ fún ohùn àwọn ẹgbẹ́ akọrin olóhùn ọkùnrin Welsh àti bọ́ọ̀lù àláfọwọ́-fẹsẹ̀ gbá àti èédú rẹ̀.

english: But when I was a teenager, the coal mines and the steelworks closed, and the entire area was devastated.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n nígbà tí mo wà ni ọ̀gọ̀ṣọ́, ìwakùsà èédú àti iṣẹ́-ọnà irinlílọ̀ di títìpa, tí gbogbo agbègbè náà sì ti bàjẹ́.

english: And I went there because it had one of the highest "Leave" votes in the country.
yoruba: Nígbà tí mo sì lọ síbẹ̀ nítorí ó ní ọ̀kan lára ìbo “Kúrò” tó pọ̀jù lọ ní orílẹ̀-èdè náà.

english: Sixty-two percent of the people here voted to leave the European Union.
yoruba: Ìdá méjì-lé-lọ́gọ́ta àwọn ènìyàn níbí l’ó dìbò láti fi Àjọ-Ìgbìmọ Ilẹ̀ Europe sílẹ̀.

english: And I wanted to know why.
yoruba: Mo sì fẹ́ mọ ìdí rẹ̀.

english: When I got there, I was just a bit taken aback, because the last time I went to Ebbw Vale, it looked like this.
yoruba: Nígbà tí mo débẹ̀, ó yà mí lẹ́nu díẹ̀, nítorí ìgbà tí mo lọ sí Ebbw Vale kẹ́yìn, ó rí báyìí.

english: And now, it looks like this.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n nísìnyìí, ó rí báyìí.

english: This is a new 33-million-pound college of further education that was mostly funded by the European Union.
yoruba: Ilé-ẹ̀kọ́ gíga oní owó pọ́ùn àádọ́ta-ọ̀kẹ́ 33 tuntun fún ìtẹ̀síwájú ètò-ẹ̀kọ́ tí púpọ̀ nínú owó yẹn wá láti ọwọ́ Àjọ-Ìgbìmọ Ilẹ̀ Europe.

english: And this is the new sports center that's at the middle of 350-million-pound regeneration project that's being funded by the European Union.
yoruba: Ibi eré-ìdárayá tuntun rè é tí ó wà láàárín iṣẹ́ àkànṣe ìsọdọ̀tun oní àádọ́ta-ọ̀kẹ́ 350 owó pọ́ùn tí Àjọ-Ìgbìmọ Ilẹ̀ Europe ń ṣe onígbọ̀wọ rẹ̀.

english: And this is the new 77-million-pound road-improvement scheme, and there's a new train line, a new railway station, and they're all being funded by the European Union.
yoruba: Èyí ni ètò àtúnṣe ọ̀nà tuntun oní owó póùn àádọ́ta-ọ̀kẹ́ 77, ojú ọ̀nà ọkọ̀-ojú-irin tuntun náà wà, ibùdókọ̀ àwọn ọkọ̀ ojúurin tuntun, tí ó jẹ́ wí pé Àjọ-Ìgbìmọ Ilẹ̀ Europe ló ń ṣe onígbọ̀wọ gbogbo rẹ̀.

english: And it's not as if any of this is a secret, because there's big signs like this everywhere.
yoruba: Kì í sì ṣe wí pé ìkankan nínú àwọn wọ̀nyìí jẹ́ àṣìírí, nítorí àwọn àpẹẹrẹ ǹlá bí èyí wà káàkiri.

english: [EU Funds: Investing in Wales]
yoruba: [Owó Ìgbọ̀wọ́ EU: ìdókòwò nínú Wales].

english: I had this sort of weird sense of unreality, walking around the town.
yoruba: Mò ti ní ìmọ̀lára àjòjì yìí nípa àìjóòótọ́ bí mo ṣe ń rìn káàkiri ìlú náà.

english: And it came to a head when I met this young man in front of the sports center.
yoruba: Ó wá sími lórí nígbà tí mo pàde ọ̀dọ́mọkùnrin kan níwáju ibi eré ìdárayá náà.

english: And he told me that he had voted to leave, because the European Union had done nothing for him.
yoruba: Ó sọ fún mi wí pé òún ti dìbò láti kúrò, nítorí Àjọ-ìgbìmọ Ilẹ̀ Europe ò ṣe nǹkankan fún òun.

english: He was fed up with it.
yoruba: Ó ti sú u.

english: And all around town, people told me the same thing.
yoruba: Yíká gbogbo ìlú, oun kan náà ni àwọn ènìyàn ń sọ fún mi.

english: They said that they wanted to take back control, which was one of the slogans in the campaign.
yoruba: Wọ́n ní àwọn fẹ́ gba ìṣàkóso padà, èyí t’ó jẹ́ ọ̀kan lára ìpèdè nínú ìpolongo náà.

english: And they told me that they were most fed up with the immigrants and with the refugees.
yoruba: Wọ́n sọ fún mi wí pé ti àwọn àṣíkiri àti àwọn ogúnléndé ni ó tojú sú àwọn jù.

english: They'd had enough.
yoruba: Àwọ́n ti rí tó.

english: Which was odd.
yoruba: Léyìí tó ṣájòjì.

english: Because walking around, I didn't meet any immigrants or refugees.
yoruba: Torí bí mo ṣe rìn káàkiri, mi ò rí àṣíkiri tàbí ogúnléndé kankan.

english: I met one Polish woman who told me she was practically the only foreigner in town.
yoruba: Mo pàde arábìnrin ọmọ Poland kan tí ó sọ fún mi wí pé òun nìkan ni àjòjì tó wà nínú ìlú náà.

english: And when I checked the figures, I discovered that Ebbw Vale actually has one of the lowest rates of immigration in the country.
yoruba: Nígbà tí mo wo iye rẹ̀, mo rí i wí pé Ebbw Vale ní ọ̀kan lára ìgbéléwọ̀n ìṣílọ-sí-ìlú-òkèèrè-mìíràn t’ó kéré jùlọ ní orílẹ̀-èdè náà.

english: And so I was just a bit baffled, because I couldn't really understand where people were getting their information from.
yoruba: Ó fa ìpòrúru ọkàn díẹ̀ fún mi, nítorí mi ò ní ò ye ibi tí àwọn ènìyán ti ń gba ìfitónilétí wọn.

english: Because it was the right-wing tabloid newspapers which printed all these stories about immigration.
yoruba: Nítorí ìwé-ìroyìn apá-ọ̀tun l’ó ṣe àtẹ̀jáde gbogbo ìròyìn nípa ìṣílọ-sí-ìlú-òkèèrè-mìíràn wọ̀nyí.

english: And this is a very much left-wing Labour stronghold.
yoruba: Tí èyí sì fi púpọ̀ wà ní sàkání apá-òsì Iṣẹ́-ṣíṣe.

english: But then after the article came out, this woman got in touch with me.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n lẹ́yìn tí àpilẹ̀kọ náà jáde, obìnrin yìí kàn sí mi.

english: And she was from Ebbw Vale, and she told me about all this stuff that she'd seen on Facebook.
yoruba: Ó wá láti Ebbw Vale, ó sọ fún mi nípa gbogbo àwọn nǹkan yìí t’ó ti rí lórí Facebook.

english: I was like, "What stuff?
yoruba: Mo béèrè wí pé, “nǹkan wo?

english: " And she said it was all this quite scary stuff about immigration, and especially about Turkey.
yoruba: “Ó sọ wí pé gbogbo àwọn nǹkan abanilẹ́rù yìí nípa ìṣílọ-sí-ìlú-òkèèrè-mìíràn, pàápàá jùlọ nípa orílẹ̀-èdeTurkey.

english: So I tried to find it.
yoruba: Torí náà mo gbìyànjú láti sàwárí rẹ̀.

english: But there was nothing there.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n kò sí nǹkankan níbẹ̀.

english: Because there's no archive of ads that people had seen or what had been pushed into their news feeds.
yoruba: Nítorí kò sí àká ti ìpolówó tí àwọn ènìyán ti rí tàbí ǹnkan tí wọ́n ti tì sí ìkànnì afúnni níròyin wọn.

english: No trace of anything, gone completely dark.
yoruba: Kò sí ìtọsẹ̀ nǹkankan, ó ti dúdú pátápátá.

english: And this referendum that will have this profound effect forever on Britain -- it's already had a profound effect: the Japanese car manufacturers that came to Wales and the north east to replace the mining jobs -- they are already going because of Brexit.
yoruba: Ìbò yìí tí yóò nípa ńlá lára Britain títí-láyé -- ó wulẹ̀ ti nípa ńlá: àwọn ará Japan tí wọ́n ń ṣe ọkọ̀ ilẹ̀ tà tí wọ́n wá sí orílẹ̀-èdè Wales àti àríwá ìlà-oòrùn láti rọ́pò iṣẹ́ ìwakùsà -- wọ́n ti ń lọ nítorí Brexit.

english: And this entire referendum took place in darkness, because it took place on Facebook.
yoruba: Gbogbo ìbò yìí wáyé nínú òkùnkùn, nítorí ó wáyé lórí Facebook.

english: And what happens on Facebook stays on Facebook, because only you see your news feed, and then it vanishes, so it's impossible to research anything.
yoruba: Nǹkan tó bá sì ṣẹlẹ̀ lórí Facebook yóò dúró sórí Facebook, nítorí ìwọ nìkan lò ń rí afúnni níròyin rẹ, yóó sì di ofò, nítórí náà kò ṣe é ṣe láti ṣèwádìí nǹkankan.

english: So we have no idea who saw what ads or what impact they had, or what data was used to target these people.
yoruba: Torí náà a ò mọ̀ ẹni tí ó rí irú ìpolówó tàbí ipa tí wọ́n ní, tàbí ìwífún-alálàyé tí ó jẹ́ lílò láti darí ìpolówó sí àwọn ènìyàn wọ̀nyí.

english: Or even who placed the ads, or how much money was spent, or even what nationality they were.
yoruba: Tàbí ta ni ẹni t’ó fi ìpolówó náà síbẹ̀, tàbí èélòó lowó tí wọ́n ná, tàbí ọmọ orílẹ̀-èdè tí wọ́n jẹ́.

english: But Facebook does.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n Facebook mọ̀.

english: Facebook has these answers, and it's refused to give them to us.
yoruba: Facebook ní àwọn ìdáhùn wọ̀nyí, ó sì kọ̀ láti kó wọn fún wa.

english: Our parliament has asked Mark Zuckerberg multiple times to come to Britain and to give us these answers.
yoruba: Àwọn aṣòfin wa ti sọ fún Mark Zuckerberg lọ́pọ̀ ìgbà pé kó wá sí orílẹ̀-èdè Britain láti wá fún wa ní àwọn ìdáhùn wọ̀nyí.

english: And every single time, he's refused.
yoruba: Ní àsìkò kọ̀ọ̀kan, ó kọ̀ jálẹ̀.

english: And you have to wonder why.
yoruba: Tí ènìyàn sì ní láti wòye oun t’ó fa sábàbí

english: Because what I and other journalists have uncovered is that multiple crimes took place during the referendum.
yoruba: Nítorí nǹkan tí èmi àti àwọn akọ̀ròyìn mìíràn ti wú jáde ni wí pé ọ̀kẹ́ àìmọye ìwà-ọ̀daràn ló wáyé lásíkò ìbò náà.

english: And they took place on Facebook.
yoruba: Wọ́n sì wáyé lórí Facebook.

english: It's because in Britain, we limit the amount of money that you can spend in an election.
yoruba: Ìdí ni wí pé ní ilẹ̀ Britain, a fi gbèdéke sí iye owó tí ènìyàn lè ná nínú ìbò.

english: And it's because in the 19th century, people would walk around with literally wheelbarrows of cash and just buy voters.
yoruba: Ìdí sì ni wí pé ní ọ̀rún-ọdún 19, láwòmọ lítírésọ̀ àwọn ènìyàn máa ń rìn káàkiri pẹ̀lú kẹ̀kẹ́-akẹ́rù-ẹlẹ́sẹ̀-kan t’ó kún fún owó láti ra àwọn olùdìbò.

english: So we passed these strict laws to stop that from happening.
yoruba: Torí náà a ṣé àwọn òfin t’ó múná wọ̀nyí láti dẹ́kun ìyẹn kí ó má wáyé.

english: But those laws don't work anymore.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n àwọn òfin wọ̀nyẹn kò ṣiṣẹ́ mọ́.

english: This referendum took place almost entirely online.
yoruba: Ìbò yìí wáyé lápapọ̀ lórí ẹ̀rọ ayélukára-bí-ajere.

english: And you can spend any amount of money on Facebook or on Google or on YouTube ads and nobody will know, because they're black boxes.
yoruba: Ènìyàn sì lè ná owó iye-kí-ye lórí Facebook tàbí lórí Google tàbí ìpolówó lórí YouTube tí ẹnikẹ́ni ò ní mọ̀, nítorí àwọn ohun tí ó fara sin ni wọ́n.

english: And this is what happened.
yoruba: Ohun t’ó ṣẹlẹ̀ rè é.

english: We've actually got no idea of the full extent of it.
yoruba: A ò ní ìmọ̀ kankan nípa bó ṣe tó ní kíkún.

english: But we do know that in the last days before the Brexit vote, the official "Vote Leave" campaign laundered nearly three quarters of a million pounds through another campaign entity that our electoral commission has ruled was illegal, and it's referred it to the police.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n a mọ̀ wí pé ní àwọn ọjọ́ t’ó kẹ́yìn kí ìbò Brexit ó tó bẹ̀rẹ̀, ìpolongo gangan “Dìbo Kúrò” fẹ́rẹ̀ẹ́ kó ìdá mẹ́ta àádọ́ta-ọ̀kẹ́ owó póùn kan mì nípasẹ̀ ìpolongo mìíràn tí àjọ elétò ìdìbò wa ti pàṣẹ pé kò bófinmu, tí ó sì tari rẹ̀ sí akoto àwọn ọlọ́pàá.

english: And with this illegal cash, "Vote Leave" unleashed a fire hose of disinformation.
yoruba: Pẹ̀lú owó tí ò bófinmu yìí, “Dìbo Kúrò” ṣe ìtúsílẹ̀ ọ̀pá ìpaná ìfitónilétí-aṣinilọ́nà.

english: Ads like this.
yoruba: Àwọn ìpolówó bí èyí.

english: [Turkey's 76m people joining the EU]
yoruba: [Àádọ́ta-Ọ̀kẹ́ 76 àwọn ènìyan orílẹ̀-èdè Turkey tí wọ́n ń darapọ̀ mọ́ EU].

english: This is a lie, it's a total lie.
yoruba: Irọ́ ni èyí, irọ́ pátápátá ni.

english: Turkey is not joining the European Union.
yoruba: Orílẹ̀-èdè Turkey ò darapọ̀ mọ́ Àjọ-Ìgbìmọ Ilẹ̀ Europe.

english: There's not even any discussions of it joining the European Union.
yoruba: Kò ti ẹ̀ sí ìjíròrò kankan nípa rẹ̀ pé ó fẹ́ darapọ̀ mọ́ Àjọ-Ìgbìmọ Ilẹ̀ Europe.

english: And most of us, we never saw these ads, because we were not the target of them.
yoruba: Ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ wa, a ò rí ìpolówó yìí rárá, nítorí àwa kọ́ ni wọ́n ń darí rẹ̀ sí.

english: "Vote Leave" identified a tiny sliver of people who it identified as persuadable, and they saw them.
yoruba: “Dìbo Kúrò” ṣèdámọ̀ àwọn ènìyàn díẹ̀ t’ó ṣèdámọ̀ wọn gẹ́gẹ́ bí ẹni tí a lè yí-lọ́kàn-padà, wọ́n sì rí wọn.

english: And the only reason we are seeing these now is because parliament forced Facebook to hand them over.
yoruba: Ìdí kan pàtó tí a ṣe ń rí àwọn wọ̀nyí nísisìyí ni wí pé àwọn aṣòfin ti fipá mú Facebook láti kó wọn sílẹ̀.

english: And maybe you think, "Well, it was just a bit of overspending.
yoruba: Bóyá o rò wí pé, “ Dáradára, ìnákúnàá díẹ̀ ni ó jẹ́.

english: It's a few lies.
yoruba: Irọ́ díẹ̀ ni.

english: " But this was the biggest electoral fraud in Britain for 100 years.
yoruba: “ Ṣùgbọ́n èyí ni ìbo jìbìtì t’ó tóbi jù nílẹ̀ Britain láàárín 100 ọdún.

english: In a once-in-a-generation vote that hinged upon just one percent of the electorate.
yoruba: Ní ìbò ẹ̀kan-láàrín-ìran-kan tó gbára lé ìdá kan ṣoṣo àwọn olùdìbò.

english: And it was just one of the crimes that took place in the referendum.
yoruba: Ó jẹ́ ọ̀kan lára àwọn ìwà-ọ̀daràn t’ó wáyé nínú ìdìbò náà.

english: There was another group, which was headed by this man, Nigel Farage, the one to the right of Trump.
yoruba: Ẹgbẹ́ kan tún wà, tí ọkùnrin yìí jẹ́ olórí wọn, Nigel Farage, èyí tó wà lápá ọ̀tun Trump.

english: And his group, "Leave.
yoruba: Ẹgbẹ́ rẹ̀, “Kúrò ní EU” -- òun náà rúfin bákan náà.

english: EU" -- it also broke the law.
yoruba: Ó rúfin ètò-ìdìbo ilẹ̀ Britain àti ìwífún-alálàyé òfin Britain, wọ́n sì ń ṣe ìtọ́kasí rẹ̀ fún àwọn ọlọ́pà.

english: It broke British electoral laws and British data laws, and it's also being referred to the police.
yoruba: Ọkùnrin yìí, Arron Banks, òun ló ṣe onígbọ̀wọ́ ìpolongo yìí.

english: And this man, Arron Banks, he funded this campaign.
yoruba: Ní ọ̀rọ̀ tó yátọ̀ gédéngbé, wọ́n ń ṣe ìtọ́kasí rẹ̀ fún àwọn Àjọ tó ń rí sí Ìwà-ọ̀daràn Àpapọ̀ wa, tọ̀dọ tiwa tó ṣe déédéé FBI, nítorí àjọ elétò ìdìbo wa ti sọ wí pé àwọn ò mọ ibi tí owó rẹ̀ ti wá.

english: And in a completely separate case, he's being referred to our National Crime Agency, our equivalent of the FBI, because our electoral commission has concluded they don't know where his money came from.
yoruba: Tàbí tó bá ṣe wí pé ọmọ ilẹ̀ Britain ni.

english: Or if it was even British.
yoruba: Mi ò ti ẹ̀ ní mẹ́nu ba àwọn irọ́ tí Arron Banks ti sọ nípa àjọṣepọ̀ ìkọ̀kọ rẹ̀ pèlú ìjọba orílẹ̀-ède Russia.

english: And I'm not even going to go into the lies that Arron Banks has told about his covert relationship with the Russian government.
yoruba: Àbí asìkò àjòji ìpàde Farage pẹ̀lú Julian Assange àti pẹ̀lu ọ̀rẹ́ Trump, Roger Stone, tí wọ́n ti fẹ̀sùn kàn, lẹ́sẹ̀kẹsẹ̀ ṣíwáju kí Wikileak tó ṣe àgbéjáde méjì ṣànkò-ṣànkò, léyìí tí méjééjì ṣe àǹfààní fún Trump.

english: Or the weird timing of Nigel Farage's meetings with Julian Assange and with Trump's buddy, Roger Stone, now indicted, immediately before two massive WikiLeaks dumps, both of which happened to benefit Donald Trump.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n mà á sọ fún ọ wí pé Brexit àti Trump jọ wọnú arawọn ni.

english: But I will tell you that Brexit and Trump were intimately entwined.
yoruba: Okùnrin yìí sọ fúnmi wí pé Brexit ni àwokòtò-ìṣàyẹ̀wò fún Trump.

english: This man told me that Brexit was the petri dish for Trump.
yoruba: A sì mọ̀ wí pé àwọn ènìyàn yìí kan náà, àwọn ilé-iṣẹ́ kan náà, ìwífún-alálàyé kan náà, ìlànà-ìṣe kan náà, ìṣàmúlò ìkórìra àti ìbẹ̀rù kan náà ni.

english: And we know it's the same people, the same companies, the same data, the same techniques, the same use of hate and fear.
yoruba: Nǹkan tí wọ́n ń fi sóri Facebook nìyí.

english: This is what they were posting on Facebook.
yoruba: Mi ò sì fẹ́ pe èyí gan-an nírọ́.

english: And I don't even want to call this a lie, [Immigration without assimilation equals invasion] because it feels more like a hate crime to me.
yoruba: [ìṣílọ-sí-ìlú-òkèèrè-mìíràn láìsí ìgbaniwọlé túmọ̀ sí ìdótì] Nítorí ó jọ ìwà-ọ̀daràn ju ìkórìra lọ sí mi.

english: I don't have to tell you that hate and fear are being sown online all across the world.
yoruba: Mi ò ní láti sọ fún yín wí pé ìkórìra àti ìbẹ̀rù ní wọ́n ń gbìn sórí ẹ̀rọ ayélukára káàkiri ayé.

english: Not just in Britain and America, but in France and in Hungary and Brazil and Myanmar and New Zealand.
yoruba: Kì í ṣe ní orílẹ̀-ède Britain àti America nìkan, ṣùgbọ́n ní orílẹ̀-ède France àti Hungary àti Brazil àti Myanmar àti New Zealand.

english: And we know there is this dark undertow which is connecting us all globally.
yoruba: A sì mọ̀ pé omi dúdú tó ń ṣàn kan wà tó ń so gbogbo wa pọ̀ lágbàyé.

english: And it is flowing via the technology platforms.
yoruba: Ó ṣì ń ṣàn lórí àwọn gbàgede ìmọ̀-ẹ̀rọ.

english: But we only see a tiny amount of what's going on on the surface.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n díẹ̀ nínú nǹkan tó ń lọ lókè là ń rí.

english: And I only found out anything about this dark underbelly because I started looking into Trump's relationship to Farage, into a company called Cambridge Analytica.
yoruba: Mo rí nǹkankan nípa òkùnkùn tó wà lábẹ́-inú yìí torí mo ṣẹ̀ṣẹ̀ bẹ̀rẹ̀ sí í wo àjọṣepọ̀ t’ó wà láàárín Trump àti Farage ni, sínú ilé-iṣẹ́ kan tí wọ́n ń pè ní Cambrige Analytica.

english: And I spent months tracking down an ex-employee, Christopher Wiley.
yoruba: Mo lo àìmọye oṣù tí mò ń tọpa òṣìṣẹ́-fẹ̀yìntì kan, Christopher Wiley.

english: And he told me how this company, that worked for both Trump and Brexit, had profiled people politically in order to understand their individual fears, to better target them with Facebook ads.
yoruba: Ó sì sọ fún mi bí ilé-iṣẹ́ yìí, t’ó ṣiṣẹ́ fún Trump àti Brexit, ti ṣe àkọsílẹ̀ àwọn ènìyàn ní ti òṣèlú láti lè lóye ìbẹ̀ru ẹnìkọ̀ọ̀kan wọn, láti lè darí ìpolówó Facebook sí wọn.

english: And it did this by illicitly harvesting the profiles of 87 million people from Facebook.
yoruba: Ó sì ṣe èyí nípasẹ̀ kíkórè ìsọfúnni àwọn ènìyàn àádọ́ta-okẹ́ 87 lórí Facebook ní ọ̀nà àìbófinmu.

english: It took an entire year's work to get Christopher on the record.
yoruba: Ó gba iṣẹ́ odidi ọdún kan gbáko láti lè mú Christopher sórí àkọsílẹ̀.

english: And I had to turn myself from a feature writer into an investigative reporter to do it.
yoruba: Mo sì ní láti sọ ara mi di olùjábọ̀ ìwádìí ìtọpinpin láti akọ̀ròyìn láti lè ṣe é.

english: And he was extraordinarily brave, because the company is owned by Robert Mercer, the billionaire who bankrolled Trump, and he threatened to sue us multiple times, to stop us from publishing.
yoruba: Òun náà sì ní ìgboyà aláìlẹ́gbẹ́, nítorí Robert Mercer ni ó ni ilé-iṣẹ́ náà, ọlọ́rọ̀ t’ó ṣe onígbọ̀wọ fún Trump, ó sì dúkokò láti pè wá lẹ́jọ́ ní ọ̀pọ̀ ìgbà, láti dá àtẹ̀jáde wa dúró.

english: But we finally got there, and we were one day ahead of publication.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n a pàpà dé ibẹ̀, ó ku ọjọ́ kan kí á ṣe àtẹ̀jáde.

english: We got another legal threat.
yoruba: A gba ìdúkokò ìpẹ̀lẹ́jọ́ mìíràn.

english: Not from Cambridge Analytica this time, but from Facebook.
yoruba: Kì í ṣe láti Cambridge Analytica lásíkò yìí, ṣùgbọ́n láti Facebook.

english: It told us that if we publish, they would sue us.
yoruba: Ó sọ fún wa wí pé tí a bá ṣe àtẹ̀jáde, wọ́n máa pè wá ní ẹjọ́.

english: We did it anyway.
yoruba: A ṣáà ṣe é ṣá.

english: Facebook, you were on the wrong side of history in that.
yoruba: Facebook, ihà tí ò dára nínú ìtàn ni o wà nínú ìyẹn.

english: And you were on the wrong side of history in this -- in refusing to give us the answers that we need.
yoruba: O sì wà ní ihà tí ò dára nínú ìtàn èyí -- látàrí kíkọ̀ jálẹ̀ láti fún wa ní àwọn ìdáhùn tí a nílò.

english: And that is why I am here.
yoruba: Ìdí nìyẹn tí mo fi wà níbí.

english: To address you directly, the gods of Silicon Valley.
yoruba: Láti báa yín sọ̀rọ̀ tààrà, àwọn òòṣa ti Silicon Valley.

english: Mark Zuckerberg and Sheryl Sandberg and Larry Page and Sergey Brin and Jack Dorsey, and your employees and your investors, too.
yoruba: Mark Zuckerberg àti Sheryl Sandberg àti Larry Page àti Sergy Brin àti Jack Dorsey, àti àwọn òṣìṣẹ yín àti àwọn olùdókoòwò yín, bákan náà.

english: Because 100 years ago, the biggest danger in the South Wales coal mines was gas.
yoruba: Nítorí 100 ọdún sẹ́yìn, ewu t’ó tóbi jù ní àwọn ìwa èédú ní South Wales ni afẹ́fẹ́ ìdáná.

english: Silent and deadly and invisible.
yoruba: Dákẹ́ rọ́rọ́ àti tí-ń-ṣekú-pani tí a kò lè rí sójú.

english: It's why they sent the canaries down first to check the air.
yoruba: Ìdí nìyí tí wọ́n fi rán àwọn ẹyẹ ìbákà lọ sínú ilẹ̀ láti kọ́kọ́ lọ yẹ afẹ́fẹ́ náà wò.

english: And in this massive, global, online experiment that we are all living through, we in Britain are the canary.
yoruba: Nínú àyèwo orí ẹ̀rọ ayélukára ti àgbàyé tí ó tóbi tí à ń là kọjá lọ́wọ́ yìí, awa tí a wà ní orílẹ̀-ède Britain ni ẹyẹ ìbákà.

english: We are what happens to a western democracy when a hundred years of electoral laws are disrupted by technology.
yoruba: Àwa ni ohun t’ó ṣẹlẹ̀ sí ìjọba àwarawa ní ihà-ìwọ̀-oòrùn nígbà tí ìmọ̀-ẹ̀rọ ti ṣe ìdíwọ́ fún òfin ètò-ìdìbo ọgọ́run ọdún.

english: Our democracy is broken, our laws don't work anymore, and it's not me saying this, it's our parliament published a report saying this.
yoruba: Ìjọba àwarawa ti fọ́ yángá, àwọn òfin wa ò ṣiṣẹ́ mọ́, èmi kọ́ ni mò ń sọ èyí, àwọn aṣòfin wa ni wọ́n tẹ àtẹ̀jáde ìhìn t’ó ń sọ èyí.

english: This technology that you have invented has been amazing.
yoruba: Ìmọ̀-ẹ̀rọ tí o ti ṣàpilẹ̀ṣe rẹ̀ yìí yanilẹ́nu.

english: But now, it's a crime scene.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n báyìí, ọ̀gangan-ibi-ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ ìwà-ọ̀daran ni.

english: And you have the evidence.
yoruba: O sì ní ẹ̀rí.

english: And it is not enough to say that you will do better in the future.
yoruba: Kò sì tó láti sọ wí pé o ó ṣe dáadáa lọ́jọ́ iwájú.

english: Because to have any hope of stopping this from happening again, we have to know the truth.
yoruba: Torí láti ní ìrètí kankan nípa dídáwọ́ èyí dúró láti má ṣẹlẹ̀ mọ́, a ní láti mọ òtítọ́.

english: And maybe you think, "Well, it was just a few ads.
yoruba: Bóyá o sì ń rò, “Ó dáa, àwọn ìpolówó díẹ̀ náà ni.

english: And people are smarter than that, right?
yoruba: Àwọn ènìyán sì gbọ́n ju ìyẹn lọ, àbí?

english: " To which I would say, "Good luck with that.
yoruba: Ní èyí tí mo máa sọ wí pé, “kòngẹ́ ire pẹ̀lú ìyẹn.

english: " Because what the Brexit vote demonstrates is that liberal democracy is broken.
yoruba: Nítorí nǹkan tí ìbo Brexit ṣàpèjúwe rẹ̀ ni wí pé ẹ̀tọ̀ ìjọba àwarawa ti fọ́.

english: And you broke it.
yoruba: Ẹ̀yin lẹ si sì fọ́ ọ.

english: This is not democracy -- spreading lies in darkness, paid for with illegal cash, from God knows where.
yoruba: Èyí kì í ṣe ìjọba àwarawa -- fífọ́n irọ́ ká nínú ọ̀kùnkùn, tí wọ́n fi owó tí ò bófinmu san, láti ibi t’ó jẹ́ pé Ọlọ́run ló mọ̀.

english: It's subversion, and you are accessories to it.
yoruba: Ìyípo ni, ẹ̀yin lẹ sì ṣe àtìlẹyìn fún un.

english: Our parliament has been the first in the world to try to hold you to account, and it's failed.
yoruba: Ilé aṣòfin wa jẹ́ àkọ́kọ́ ní gbogbo àgbáyé t’ó gbíyànjú láti mú u ọ ṣàláyé nǹkan tí ẹ ṣe, ó sì kùnà.

english: You are literally beyond the reach of British law -- not just British laws, this is nine parliaments, nine countries are represented here, who Mark Zuckerberg refused to come and give evidence to.
yoruba: Ẹ ti kọjá àrọ́wọ́tó òfin ilẹ̀ Britain – kì í ṣe òfin Britain nìkan, ọ̀wọ́ aṣòfin mẹsàn-án rè é, orílẹ̀-èdè mẹ́sàn-án ni ó ní aṣojú níbí, tí Mark Zukerberg kọ̀ jálẹ̀ láti wá fi ẹ̀rí fún.

english: And what you don't seem to understand is that this is bigger than you.
yoruba: Nǹkan tí ò sì yé e yín ni wí pé èyí tóbi jù ẹ̀yin gan-an lọ.

english: And it's bigger than any of us.
yoruba: Ó sì tóbi ju ẹnìkànkan wa lọ.

english: And it is not about left or right or "Leave" or "Remain" or Trump or not.
yoruba: Kì í ṣe nípa òsì tàbí ọ̀tún tàbí “Kúrò” tàbí “Dúró” tàbí Trump tàbí ẹlòmíràn.

english: It's about whether it's actually possible to have a free and fair election ever again.
yoruba: Ó jẹ́ nípa bóyá ó ṣe é ṣe láti ní ètò-ìdìbò tí yóò lọ ní ìrọwọ́-rọṣẹ̀ mọ́.

english: Because as it stands, I don't think it is.
yoruba: Tórí bó ṣe rí yìí, mi ò rò bẹ́ẹ̀.

english: And so my question to you is, is this what you want?
yoruba: Ìbéèrè mi síi yín ni, ṣe nǹkan tí ẹ fẹ́ rèé?

english: Is this how you want history to remember you: as the handmaidens to authoritarianism that is on the rise all across the world?
yoruba: Ṣé bí ẹ ṣe fẹ́ kí ìtàn ó rántíi yín rè é: gẹ́gẹ́ bi olùrànlọ́wọ́ fún ìjọba apàṣẹ wàá tó ń dìde káàkiri gbogbo àgbáyé?

english: Because you set out to connect people.
yoruba: Nítorí ẹ bẹ̀rẹ̀ láti so àwọn ènìyàn pọ̀ ni.

english: And you are refusing to acknowledge that the same technology is now driving us apart.
yoruba: Ẹ sì ń kọ̀ láti gbà pé ìmọ̀-ẹ̀rọ yìí kan náà ń pín wa níyà.

english: And my question to everybody else is, is this what we want: to let them get away with it, and to sit back and play with our phones, as this darkness falls?
yoruba: Ìbéèrè mi sí gbogbo ènìyàn tókù ni pé, ṣé nǹkan tí a fẹ́ rè é: láti jẹ́ kí wọ́n mú u jẹ, ka sì jókòó ka máa fi ẹ̀rọ-ìbánisọ̀rọ wa ṣeré, bí òkùnkùn yìí ṣe ń kù?

english: The history of the South Wales Valleys is of a fight for rights.
yoruba: Ìtan South Wales Valleys jẹ́ ti ìjà fún ẹ̀tọ́.

english: And this is not a drill -- it's a point of inflection.
yoruba: Èyí kìí ṣe ìbáwí -- kókó àyípada ni.

english: Democracy is not guaranteed, and it is not inevitable, and we have to fight and we have to win and we cannot let these tech companies have this unchecked power.
yoruba: Ìjọba àwarawa ò dájú, kò sì ṣe é fẹ́kù, a ní láti jà a sì ní láti borí a ò lè jẹ́ kí àwọn ilé-iṣẹ́ ìmọ̀-ẹ̀rọ ní agbára tí ò ṣe é yẹ̀ lọ́wọ́ wọ̀ yìí.

english: It's up to us -- you, me and all of us.
yoruba: Ó dọwọ́ọ wa -- ìwọ, èmi àti gbogbo wa.

english: We are the ones who have to take back control.
yoruba: Àwa la ní láti gba ìṣàkóso padà.

english: How we can make energy more affordable for low-income families.
yoruba: Bí a ṣe lè jẹ́ kí agbára rọjú fún àwọn ẹbí tí owó tí ìpawó wọ̀lé wọn kéré.

english: So, as a child, I used to spend all of my time at my great-grandmother's house.
yoruba: Gẹ́gẹ́ bí ọmọdé, mo máa ń lo gbogbo àsìkò mi ní ilé ìyá-àgbà ìyá mi.

english: On hot, humid, summer days, I would dash across the floor and stick my face in front of her only air conditioner.
yoruba: Ní àwọn ọjọ́ tó bá gbóná, lásìkò ooru, mo máa sáré kọjá nílẹ̀ ma sì gbójú mi síwájú ẹ̀rọ amúlétutù wọn kan ṣoṣo.

english: But I didn't realize that that simple experience, though brief, was a privileged one in our community.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n mi ò mọ̀ pé ìrírí kékeré yẹn, bó tilẹ̀ jẹ́ péréte, jẹ́ àǹfààní kan ní àwùjọ wa.

english: Growing up, stories of next-door neighbors having to set up fake energy accounts or having to steal energy seemed normal to me.
yoruba: Nígbà tí mò ń dàgbà, ìtan àwọn aládùgbo nílé-kejì tí wọ́n ṣe àgbékalẹ̀ ayédèrú àpò àṣùwọn agbára tàbí tí wọ́n ní láti jí agbára jẹ́ nǹkan t’ó tọ́ sí mi.

english: During the winter, struggling to get warm, my neighbors would have no choice but to bypass the meter after their heat was shut off, just to keep their family comfortable for one more day.
yoruba: Lásíkò òtútù, títiraka láti jẹ́ kí ará lọ́, àwọn aládùgbò mi ò ní àǹfààní kankan ju wí pé kí wọ́n pẹ́ mítà kọjá lẹ́yìn tí wọ́n bá ti pa oru wọn, láti lè fi ará dẹ ẹbí wọn fún ọjọ́ kan sí i.

english: These kinds of dangerous incidents can take root when people are faced with impossible choices.
yoruba: Irú àwọn ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ tó léwu wọ̀nyí lè gbilẹ̀ nígbà tí àwọn ènìyàn bá ń kojú àwọn àǹfààní yíyàn tí ò ṣe é ṣe.

english: In the US, the average American spends three percent of their income on energy.
yoruba: Ní orílẹ̀-ède US, ọ̀gbọ̀ ọmọ ilẹ̀ America máa ń ná ìdá mẹ́ta owó tí wọ́n ń gbà lórí agbára.

english: In contrast, low-income and rural populations can spend 20, even 30 percent of their income on energy.
yoruba: Ní ìdàkejì, ìpawó wọlé tó kéré àti iye àwọn ènìyàn nígbèríko lè ná ìda ogún, kódà ọgbọ̀n nínú owó tí wọ́n ń gbà lórí agbára.

english: In 2015, this caused over 25 million people to skip meals to provide power to their homes.
yoruba: Ní ọdún 2015, èyí jẹ́ kí àádọ́ta-ọ̀kẹ́ mẹ́ẹ̀dọ́gbọ̀n ènìyàn fi ebi panú láti pèse agbára ní ilé wọn.

english: This is when energy becomes a burden.
yoruba: Àsìkò yìí ni agbára di ìṣòro.

english: But energy burdens are so much more than just a number.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n àwọn ìṣòro agbára pọ̀ gan-an ju iye kan lọ.

english: They present impossible and perilous choices: Do you take your child to get her flu medicine, or do you feed her?
yoruba: Wọ́n máa ń ṣe àgbékalẹ̀ àwọn ẹ̀yàn tí ò ṣe é ṣe tó jẹ́ abéwudé: Ṣé wàá mú ọmọọ̀ rẹ lọ gba òògùn àrùn-ọlọ́jẹ̀-ọ̀nà-èémí rẹ̀, àbí kí o bọ́ ọ?

english: Or do you keep her warm?
yoruba: Àbí ṣé kí o jẹ́ kí ara rẹ̀ máa lọ́?

english: It's an impossible choice, and nearly every month, seven million people choose between medicine and energy.
yoruba: Ẹ̀yàn tí ò ṣe é ṣe ni, ó sì fẹ́rẹ̀ẹ́ jẹ́ pé lóṣooṣù, àádọ́ta-ọ̀kẹ́ méje ènìyàn máa ń yàn láàárín òògùn àti agbára.

english: This exposes a much larger and systemic issue.
yoruba: Èyí ń tú àṣìírí ọ̀rọ̀ t’ó tóbi tó sì gba ètò.

english: Families with high energy burdens are disproportionately people of color, who spend more per square foot than their white counterparts.
yoruba: Àwọn ẹbí tí wọ́n ní ìṣòro agbára tó ga ni àwọn ènìyàn aláwọ̀ dúdú, tí wọ́n máa ń náwó ju ìwọn ẹsẹ̀ kan yàtọ̀ sí àwọn akẹgbẹ́ wọn tí wọ́n jẹ́ aláwọ̀ funfun.

english: But it's also nurses, veterans and even schoolteachers who fall into the mass of 37 million people a year who are unable to afford energy for their most basic needs.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n àwọn olùtọ́-ilé-ìwòsàn, àwọn àgbà-ọ̀jẹ̀ àti àwọn olùkọ́ nílé-ẹ̀kọ́ wà nínú àwọn àádọ́ta-ọ̀kẹ́ mẹ́tà-dín-lógójì ènìyàn lọ́dún tí wọn ò níkàpá agbára fún àwọn ohun èlo kòṣe é má nìí jùlọ wọn.

english: As a result, those with high energy burdens have a greater likelihood of conditions like heart disease and asthma.
yoruba: Nítorí èyí, àwọn tí wọ́n ní ìṣòra agbára tó ga ṣe é ṣe kí wọ́n ní àwọn àrùn bi àrùn ọkàn àti àrun séèémí-séèémí.

english: Look -- given our rockets to Mars and our pocket-sized AI, we have the tools to address these systemic inequities.
yoruba: Ẹ wòó – pẹ̀lú bàlú ayáraféfé wa tó lọ sí máásì àti AI tí ò ju àpò lọ, a ní àwọn irinṣẹ́ láti yanjú àwọn kùdiẹ̀-kudiẹ ètò wọ̀nyí.

english: The technology is here.
yoruba: Ìmọ̀-ẹ̀rọ náà wà débi.

english: Cost of renewables, insulation, microgrids and smart home technology are all decreasing.
yoruba: Iye owó ìsọdọ̀tun, bíbo oru, àkójọpọ̀ agbára àti imọ̀-ẹ̀rọ agbára inú-ilé gbogbo ti ń dínkù.

english: However, even as we approach cost parity, the majority of those who own solar earn much more than the average American.
yoruba: Síbẹ̀, pẹ̀lu bí a ṣe ń súmọ́ ìdọ́gba iye owó, ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ àwọn ti wọ́n ní agbára ìtọ̀sán-oòrùn ń pawó ju ọ̀pọ ọmọ ilẹ̀ America lọ.

english: This is why, when I was 22, I founded the nonprofit RETI.
yoruba: Ìdí nìyí, nígbà tí mo wà lọ́mọdún méjì-lé-lógún, mo dá ilé-iṣẹ́ àìjère RETI sílẹ̀.

english: Our mission is to alleviate energy burdens by working with communities, utilities and government agencies alike to provide equitable access to clean energy, energy efficiency and energy technology.
yoruba: Afojúsùn wa ni láti sọ ìṣòro agbára di fúfúyẹ́ nípa ìṣiṣẹ́ pẹ̀lú àwọn àwùjọ, àwọn ilé-iṣẹ́ tó ń pèse agbára àti àwọn aṣojú ìjọba bákan náà láti pèse àǹfààní adọ́gba sí agbára aláìléwu, àdínkù agbára àti ìmọ̀-ẹ̀rọ agbára.

english: But there's no one way to solve this.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n kò sí ọ̀nà kan ṣoṣo láti yanjú èyí.

english: I believe in the power of local communities, in the transforming effect of relationships.
yoruba: Mo nígbàgbọ́ nínú agbára ní àwọn àwùjọ agbègbè, nínú àyípadà ipa àjọṣepọ̀.

english: So we start by working directly with the communities that have the highest energy burdens.
yoruba: A bẹ̀rẹ̀ pẹ̀lu ṣíṣe iṣẹ́ tààrà pẹ̀lú àwọn àwùjọ tí wọ́n ní ìṣòro agbára tó gajù.

english: We host workshops and events for communities to learn about energy poverty, and how making even small updates to their homes like better insulation for windows and water heaters can go a long way to maximize efficiency.
yoruba: A ṣe ìpàdé àkànṣe-iṣẹ́ àti àwọn ètò fún àwọn àwùjọ láti kọ́ nípa òṣi agbára, àti bí ṣíṣe ìsọdọ̀tun kékeré sí ilé-wọn bíi bíbo-oru fún ojú fèrèsé àti amómi-gbóná ṣe lè ṣe púpọ̀ láti ṣàmúlo àdínkù agbára.

english: We're connecting neighborhoods to community solar and spearheading community-led smart home research and installation programs to help families bring down their energy bills.
yoruba: À ń so àwọn agbègbè mọ́ agbára ìtọ̀sán-òrùn àwùjọ a sì ń léwájú ìwádìí ìgbésẹ̀-àwùjọ lórí ilé aládàṣe àti àwọn èto ṣíṣe àtò láti lè bá àwọn ẹbí mú owó agbára wálè.

english: We're even working directly with elected officials, advocating for more equitable pricing, because to see this vision of energy equity and resilience succeed, we have to work together sustainably.
yoruba: A tún ṣiṣẹ́ tààrà pẹ̀lú àwọn aṣojú tí wọ́n fíbò yàn, tí à ń jà fún owo adọ́gba, nítori láti jẹ́ kí ìran agbára adọ́gba àti aláìléwu kẹ́sẹjárí, a ní láti ṣiṣẹ́ papọ̀ pẹ̀lú ìfọwọ́sowọ́pọ̀.

english: Now, the US spends over three billion a year on energy bill payment assistance.
yoruba: Ní báyìí, orílẹ̀-ède US ń ná ju bílíọ́nù mẹ́ta lọ́dún lórí ìrànlọ́wọ́ sísan owó agbára.

english: And these programs do help millions of people, but they're only able to help a fraction of those in need.
yoruba: Àwọn ètò wọ̀nyí máa ń ran àádọ́ta-ọ̀kẹ́ ènìyàn lọ́wọ́, ṣùgbọ́n apá kan nínú àwọn aláìní ni wọ́n lè pèsè ìrànlọ́wọ́ fún.

english: In fact, there is a 47-billion-dollar home-energy affordability gap, so assistance alone is not sustainable.
yoruba: Lóòótọ́, bílíọ́nù mẹ́tà-dín-láàdọ́ta àlàfo ìníkápá agbára-ilé ló wà, nítorí náà ìrànlọ́wọ́ nìkan ò tó.

english: But by building energy equity and resilience into our communities, we can assure fair and impartial access to energy that is clean, reliable and affordable.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n pẹ̀lu ìṣẹ̀da agbára adọ́gba àti aláìléwu nínú àwùjọ wa, a lè ṣe ìdánilójú àǹfààní adọ́gba àti aláìṣègbè sí agbára tí ò léwu, tó ṣe é gbáralé tó sì rọjú.

english: At scale, microgrid technology, clean technology and energy efficiency dramatically improve public health.
yoruba: Lórí ìwọ̀n, ìmọ̀-ẹ̀rọ àkójọpọ̀ agbára, ìmọ̀-ẹ̀rọ aláìléwu àti àdínkù agbára máa ń mú ìdàgbàsókè bá ìlera gbogbogbò bí eré.

english: And for those with high energy burdens, it can help them reclaim 20 percent of their income -- 20 percent of a person's income who's struggling to make ends meet.
yoruba: Fún àwọn tí wọ́n ní ìṣòro agbára tó ga, ó lè bá wọn gbá ìda ogún owó tí wọ́n ń gbà padà -- ìda ogún owó tí ènìyàn ń gbà tó ń tiraka láti wá oúnjẹ òjọ́.

english: This is life-changing.
yoruba: Èyí ń yí ìgbésíayé padà.

english: This is an opportunity for families to use their energy savings to sponsor their future.
yoruba: Àǹfààní rèé fún àwọn ẹbí láti lo àdínkù owó-agbára láti ṣe ìgbọ̀wọ́ ọjọ́-iwájú wọn.

english: I think back to my great-grandmother and her neighbors, the impossible choices that they had to make and the effect it had on our whole community.
yoruba: Mo máa ń ronú padà sí ìyá àgbà ìyá mi àti àwọn alájọgbé wọn, àwọn àǹfààní yíyàn tí ò ṣe é ṣe tí wọ́n ní láti ṣe àti ipa tó ní lórí gbogbo àwùjọ.

english: But this is not just about them.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n èyí kìí ṣe nípa wọn nìkan.

english: There are millions nationwide having to make the same impossible choices today.
yoruba: Àádọ́ta-ọ̀kẹ́ lágbàyé ni wọ́n ń ṣe irú àǹfààní yíyàn tí ò ṣe é ṣe yìí kan náà lónì.

english: And I know high energy burdens are a tremendous barrier to overcome, but through relationships with communities and technology, we have the paths to overcome them.
yoruba: Mo mọ̀ pé ìṣòro agbára ńlá jẹ́ wàhálà kan tó pọ̀ láti borí, ṣùgbọ́n nípasẹ̀ àjọṣepọ̀ pẹ̀lú àwọn àwùjọ àti ìmọ̀-ẹ̀rọ, a ní àwọn ọ̀nà láti borí wọn.

english: And when we do, we will all be more resilient.
yoruba: Nígbà tí a bá sì ṣe bẹ́ẹ̀, gbogbo wa ni ara wá máa túbọ̀ le sí i

english: Thank you.
yoruba: Ẹ ṣeun.

english: Can we stop climate change by removing CO2 from the air?
yoruba: Ǹjẹ́ a lè dá àyípadà ojú ọjọ́ dúró pẹ̀lu yíyọ CO2 kúrò nínú afẹ́fẹ́?

english: To avoid dangerous climate change, we're going to need to cut emissions rapidly.
yoruba: Láti dènà àyípadà ojú ọjọ́ tó léwu, a máa nílò láti gé ìtúsílẹ̀ kù kíákíá.

english: That should be a pretty uncontentious statement, certainly with this audience.
yoruba: Ìyẹ́n gbọ́dọ̀ jẹ́ ọ̀rọ̀ tí ò mú awuyewuye dání, ní ìdánilójú pẹ̀lú àwọn olùgbọ́ yìí.

english: But here's something that's slightly more contentious: it's not going to be enough.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n nǹkankan rèé tó lè fa awuyewuye díẹ̀ lọ́wọ́: kò ní tó.

english: We will munch our way through our remaining carbon budget for one and a half degrees in a few short years, and the two degree budget in about two decades.
yoruba: A máa rápálá wáyè kọjá ìṣúná èédú tókù fún àléfà kan àtàbọ̀ ní ọdún tó kéré díẹ̀, àti ìṣúná àléfà méjì ní bíi èwá-ọdún méjì.

english: We need to not only cut emissions extremely rapidly, we also need to take carbon dioxide out of the atmosphere.
yoruba: A ò nílò láti gé ìtúsílẹ̀ kù kíákíá nìkan, a tún nílò láti mú òyì-èédú kúrò ní òyì ojú-ayé.

english: Thank you.
yoruba: Ẹ ṣeun.

english: I work assessing a whole range of these proposed techniques to see if they can work.
yoruba: Mo ṣiṣẹ́ pẹ̀lu ṣíṣe àyẹ̀wo ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ àwọn ìlànà tí wọ́n dálábàá wọ̀nyí láti wò ó bóyá wọ́n lè ṣiṣẹ́.

english: We could use plants to take CO2 out, and then store it in trees, in the soil, deep underground or in the oceans.
yoruba: A lè lo àwọn nǹkan ọ̀gbìn láti mú CO2 kúrò, ká sì tọ́jú wọn sínú igi, inú iyẹ̀pẹ̀, lábẹ́ ilẹ̀ tàbí inú omi-òkun.

english: We could build large machines, so-called artificial trees, that will scrub CO2 from the air.
yoruba: A lè ṣẹ̀dá àwọn ẹ̀rọ ǹlá-ńlá, àwọn tí wọ́n ń pè ní igi àtọwọ́dá, tí yóò nu CO2 kúrò nínú afẹ́fẹ́.

english: For these ideas to be feasible, we need to understand whether they can be applied at a vast scale in a way that is safe, economic and socially acceptable.
yoruba: Kí àwọn èrò wọ̀nyí lè ṣe é ṣe, a nílò láti mọ̀ bóyá a lè ṣàmúlò wọ́n lórí ìwọ̀n ńlá lọ́nà tí ò fi ní séwu, tí yóò sì jẹ́ gbígbà fún ọrọ̀-ajé àti àwùjọ.

english: All of these ideas come with tradeoffs.
yoruba: Gbogbo èrò wọ̀nyí ló wá pẹ̀lú kùdìẹ̀kudiẹ.

english: None of them are perfect, but many have potential.
yoruba: Kò sí ìkankan nínú wọn tó pé tán, ṣùgbọ́n ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ nínú wọn ló ṣe é ṣe.

english: It's unlikely that any one of them will solve it on its own.
yoruba: Kò dájú pé ìkakan nínú wọn lè yanjú rẹ̀ lóun nìkan.

english: There is no silver bullet, but potentially together, they may form the silver buckshot that we need to stop climate change in its tracks.
yoruba: Kò sí idán Kankan, ṣùgbọ́n bóyá lápapọ̀, wọ́n lè pidán tí a nílò láti dá àyípadà ojú-ọjọ́ dúró ní orípa rẹ̀.

english: I'm working independently on one particular idea which uses natural gas to generate electricity in a way that takes carbon dioxide out of the air.
yoruba: Mò ń ṣiṣẹ́ àdáṣe lórí èrò kan tó ń lo òyì-àtilẹ̀tu láti pèse iná-mànàmáná ní ọ̀nà tí yóò mú òyì-èédú kúrò nínú afẹ́fẹ́.

english: How does that work?
yoruba: Báwo ni iyẹ́n ṣe ń ṣiṣẹ́?

english: So the Origen Power Process feeds natural gas into a fuel cell.
yoruba: Ìgbésẹ̀ Agbara Iná-mànàmáná Origen máa ń fi afẹ́fẹ́-ìdáná àtilẹ̀tu sínú pádi epo-rọ̀bì.

english: About half the chemical energy is converted into electricity, and the remainder into heat, which is used to break down limestone into lime and carbon dioxide.
yoruba: Bíi àbọ agbára kẹ́míkà ní yóò yípadà di iná-mànàmáná, àwọn ìyókù yóò sì di ooru, tí wọ́n ń lò láti sọ òkúta-ẹfun di ẹfun àti òyì-èédú.

english: Now at this point, you're probably thinking that I'm nuts.
yoruba: Níbi tí a dé yìí, bóyá ẹ̀ ń rò ó wí pé orí mi ò pé.

english: It's actually generating carbon dioxide.
yoruba: Ó ń ṣẹ̀da òyì-èédú lóòótọ́.

english: But the key point is, all of the carbon dioxide generated, both from the fuel cell and from the lime kiln, is pure, and that's really important, because it means you can either use that carbon dioxide or you can store it away deep underground at low cost.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n Kókó ibẹ̀ ni wí pé, gbogbo òyì-èédú tó ń ṣẹdá, láti inu pádi epo-rọ̀bì àti ààro ẹfun, ló mọ́ gaara, ìyẹn sì ṣe pàtàkì, nítorí ó túmọ̀ sí wí pé ẹ lè lo yálà òyì-èédú yẹn tàbí kí ẹ kó o pamọ́ sábẹ́ ilẹ̀ lówó kékeré.

english: And then the lime that you produce can be used in industrial processes, and in being used, it scrubs CO2 out of the air.
yoruba: Lẹ́yìn náà ẹfun tí ẹ ti ṣẹ̀dá yẹn lè di lílò fún ìpèsè nǹkan nílé-iṣẹ́, àti lílò ó, ó máa ń nu CO2 kúrò nínú afẹ́fẹ́.

english: Overall, the process is carbon negative.
yoruba: Lápapọ̀, ìgbésẹ̀ náà kì í pèse òyì-èédú.

english: It removes carbon dioxide from the air.
yoruba: Ó máa ń yọ òyì-èédú kúrò nínú afẹ́fẹ́ ni.

english: If you normally generate electricity from natural gas, you emit about 400 grams of CO2 into the air for every kilowatt-hour.
yoruba: Bí ẹ bá ń ṣẹ̀da iná mànàmáná látara òyì-àtilẹ̀tu dáadáa, bíi irinwó gírámu CO2 ni è ń gbé jáde sínu afẹfẹ́ fún gbogbo wákàti kílówáátì kọ̀ọ̀kan.

english: With this process, that figure is minus 600.
yoruba: Pẹ̀lú ìgbésẹ̀ yìí, fígọ̀ yẹn jẹ́ pẹ̀lú àyọkúrò ẹgbẹ̀ta.

english: At the moment, power generation is responsible for about a quarter of all carbon dioxide emissions.
yoruba: Lọ́wọ́lọ́wọ́ yìí, ìpèse agbára ló ń ṣe okùnfa bíi ìdá kan nínú ìdá mẹ́rin gbogbo ìtúsílẹ̀ òyì-èédú.

english: Hypothetically, if you replaced all power generation with this process, then you would not only eliminate all of the emissions from power generation but you would start removing emissions from other sectors as well, potentially cutting 60 percent of overall carbon emissions.
yoruba: Ní àbá, tí ẹ bá rọ́pò gbogbo ìpèse agbára pẹ̀lú ìgbésẹ̀ yìí, ẹ ò ní yọ gbogbo àwọn ìtúsílẹ̀ látara ìpèse agbára nìkan ṣùgbọ́n ẹ ó bẹ̀rẹ̀ sí yọ àwọn ìtúsílẹ̀ ní àwọn ẹ̀ka mìíràn bákan náà, gígé ìda ọgọ́ta gbogbo ìtúsílẹ̀ èédú.

english: You could even use the lime to add it directly to seawater to counteract ocean acidification, one of the other issues that is caused by CO2 in the atmosphere.
yoruba: Ẹ lè tún lo ẹfun náà láti dàápọ̀ mọ́ omi-ọ̀sà tààrà láti mú àdínkù bá ẹ̀kan omi-òkun, ọ̀kan nínú àwọn wàhálà mìíràn tí CO2 ń fà nínú òyì ojú-ayé.

english: In fact, you get more bang for your buck.
yoruba: Lóòótọ́, ẹ ó gbà ju iye tí ẹ fi sílẹ̀ lọ̀.

english: You absorb about twice as much carbon dioxide when you add it to seawater as when you use it industrially.
yoruba: Ẹ máa gba bíi ìlọ́po méjì òyì-èédú sára nígbà tí ẹ bá dàápọ̀ mọ́ omi-ọ̀sà ju tí ẹ bá lò ó nílé-iṣẹ́ lọ.

english: But this is where it gets really complicated.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n ibí yìí ló ti máa ń di àmúdijú gidi gan-an.

english: While counteracting ocean acidification is a good thing, we don't fully understand what the environmental consequences are, and so we need to assess whether this treatment is actually better than the disease that it is seeking to cure.
yoruba: Nígbà tí mímú àdínkù bá ẹ̀kan omi-òkun jẹ́ nǹkan tó dára, a ò nímọ̀ kíkún nípa nǹkan tí àbájáde rẹ̀ láwùjọ jẹ́, nítorí náà a nílò láti ṣàyèwò bóyá ìtọ́jú yìí dára lóòótọ́ ju àrùn tó fẹ́ wósàn lọ.

english: We need to put in place step-by-step governance for experiments to assess this safely.
yoruba: A nílò láti ṣèto ìdarí lẹ́sẹẹsẹ fún àwọn ìdánwò láti ṣe àyẹ̀wò yìí láìséwu.

english: And the scale: to avoid dangerous climate change, we are going to need to remove trillions -- and yes, that's trillions with a T -- trillions of tons of carbon dioxide from the atmosphere in the decades ahead.
yoruba: Ìwọn rẹ̀: láti dèna àyípadà ojú-ọjọ́ tó léwu, a máa nílò láti yọ tírílíọ́nù – bẹ́ẹ̀ni, tírílíọ́nù nìyẹn pẹ̀lú T --tírílíọ́nu tọ́ọ́nu òyì-èédú kúrò nínú òyi-ojú-ayé ní èwá-ọdún tó wà níwájú.

english: It will cost a few percent of GDP -- think defense-sized expenditure, lots of industrial activity and inevitably harmful side effects.
yoruba: Ó máa ná wa ní ìda GDP díẹ̀ -- bóyá owó-nàá ológun, ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ àmúṣe-iṣẹ́ àwọn ilé-iṣẹ́ àti àwọn àyọrísí mìíràn tó léwu tá ò lè fẹ́kù.

english: But if the scale seems enormous, it is only because of the scale of the problem that we are seeking to solve.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n tí ìwọn náà bá tóbi, nítorí ìwọ̀n ìṣòro tí a ń wá láti yanjú nìkan ni.

english: It's enormous as well.
yoruba: Ó sì tóbi bákan náà.

english: We can no longer avoid these thorny issues.
yoruba: A ò lè ma pẹ́ àwọn ìṣòro tó lágbára wọ̀nyí mọ́

english: We face risks whichever way we turn: a world changed by climate change or a world changed by climate change and our efforts to counter climate change.
yoruba: À ń kọjú ewu ní gbogbo ibi tí a bá yíjú sí: ilé-ayé tí àyípadà ojú-ọjọ́ ti yí padà tàbí ilé-ayé tí àyípadà ojú-ojú ti yí padà àti ìgbìyànju wa láti tako àyípadà ojú-ọjọ́.

english: Would that it were not so, but we can no longer afford to close our eyes, block our ears, and say la-la-la.
yoruba: Ó wùn mí kí ó má rì í bẹ́ẹ̀, ṣùgbọ́n a ò lè dijúu wa, dí etí wa, kí á má sọ la-la-la mọ́.

english: We need to grow up and face the consequences of our actions.
yoruba: A nílò láti dàgbà sókè ká sì kojú àbájáde àwọn ìwa wa.

english: Does talk of curing climate change undermine the will to cut emissions?
yoruba: Ṣé ọ̀rọ̀ nípa ìwòsan àyípadà ojú ọjọ́ ń dèna ìpinnu láti gé ìtúsílẹ̀ ni?

english: This is a real concern, so we need to emphasize the paramount importance of reducing emissions and how speculative these ideas are.
yoruba: Ẹ̀dun ọkàn tòótọ́ ni èyí, nítorí náà a nílò láti tẹnu mọ́ pàtàki mímú àdínkù bá ìtúsílẹ̀ àti bí àwọn èrò wọ̀nyí ṣe jẹ́ àhesọ-ọ̀rọ̀.

english: But having done so, we still need to examine them.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n lẹ́yìn tí a ti ṣe bẹ́ẹ̀, a ṣì nílò láti ṣe àyẹ̀wo wọn.

english: Can we cure climate change?
yoruba: Ǹjẹ́ a lè ṣe ìwòsan àyípadà ojú-ọjọ́?

english: I don't know, but we certainly can't if we don't try.
yoruba: Mi ò mọ̀, ṣùgbọ́n a ò lè mọ̀ tí a ò bá gbíyànjú.

english: We need ambition without arrogance.
yoruba: A nílò ìpinnu láìsí ìgbéraga.

english: We need the ambition to restore the atmosphere, to draw down carbon dioxide back to a level that is compatible with a stable climate and healthy oceans.
yoruba: A nílò ìpinnu láti ṣe àdápadà òyì-ojú-ayé, láti fa òyì-èédú wálẹ̀ padà sí ìpele tí ó wà ní ìbámu pẹ̀lu ojú-ọjọ́ tí kò yí pada àti omi-òkun tó lálàáfíà.

english: This will be an enormous undertaking.
yoruba: Iṣẹ́ tó pọ̀ ni eléyìí máa jẹ́.

english: You could describe it as a cathedral project.
yoruba: Ẹ lè ṣàpèjúwe rẹ̀ gẹ́gẹ́ bi iṣẹ́-àkànṣe ọjọ́-iwájú.

english: Those involved at the outset may draft the plans and dig the foundations, but they will not raise the spire to its full height.
yoruba: Àwọn tí wọ́n lọ́wọ́ nínú rẹ̀ láti ìbẹ̀rẹ́ lè ya àwòran rẹ̀ kí wọ́n sì ṣe ìfilọ́lẹ̀ rẹ̀, ṣùgbọ́n wọn ò ní gbé e dé òkè ténté.

english: That task, that privilege, belongs to our descendants.
yoruba: Iṣẹ́ yẹn, àǹfààní yẹn, àwọn tí a ṣẹ̀ sílẹ̀ ni wọ́n ni í.

english: None of us will see that day, but we must start in the hope that future generations will be able to finish the job.
yoruba: Kò sí ẹnikẹ́ni nínú wa tí yóò rí ọjọ́ náà, ṣùgbọ́n a gbọdọ̀ bẹ̀rẹ̀ pẹ̀lú ìrètí pé àwọn iran ọjọ́-iwájú máa lè parí iṣẹ́ náà.

english: So, do you want to change the world?
yoruba: Nítorí náà, ṣe ẹ fẹ́ mú àyípadà bá ilé-ayé?

english: I don't.
yoruba: Mi ò fẹ́.

english: I do not seek the change the world, but rather keep it as it's meant to be.
yoruba: Mi ò wá láti mú àyípadà bá ilé-ayé, ṣùgbọ́n láti fi sí bó ṣe yẹ kó wà.

english: Thank you.
yoruba: Ẹ ṣeun.

english: Chris Anderson: Thanks.
yoruba: Chris Anderson: Ẹ ṣeun.

english: I just want to ask you a couple of other questions.
yoruba: Mo kọ̀ fẹ́ bi yín ní àwọn ìbéèrè mìíràn bi mélòó kan ni.

english: Tell us a bit more about this idea of putting lime in the ocean.
yoruba: Ẹ sọ díẹ̀ si fúnwa nípa èro fífi ẹfun sínú omi-òkun.

english: I mean, on the face of it, it's pretty compelling -- anti-ocean acidification -- and it absorbs more CO2.
yoruba: Mò ń sọ nípa pé, bóṣe rí lójú, ó ń fanimọ́ra -- atako ẹ̀kan omi òkun -- tó sì ń gba ọ̀pọ̀ CO2 móra.

english: You talked about, we need to do an experiment on this.
yoruba: Ẹ sọ̀rọ̀ nípa pé, a nílò láti ṣe ìdánwò lórí èyí.

english: What would a responsible experiment look like?
yoruba: Báwo ni ìdánwò tó ṣe é gbáralé ṣe máa ri?

english: Tim Kruger: So I think you need to do a series of experiments, but you need to do them just very small stage-by-stage.
yoruba: Tim Kruger: mo rò wí pé ẹ nílò láti ṣe ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ ìdánwò, ṣùgbọ́n ẹ nílò láti ṣe wọ́n ní kékeré nípele-ìpele.

english: In the same way, when you're trialing a new drug, you wouldn't just go into human trials straight off.
yoruba: Ní ìlànà kan náà, nígbà tí ẹ bá ń ṣe àyẹ̀wò oògùn tuntun, ẹ ò kò ní lọ sí àyẹ̀wò lára ènìyan tààrà.

english: You would do a small experiment.
yoruba: Ẹ ó ṣe ìdánwò kékeré.

english: And so the first things to do are experiments entirely on land, in special containers, away from the environment.
yoruba: Nítorí náà nǹkan àkọ́kọ́ láti ṣe ni ìdánwò lórí ilẹ̀, nínú abọ́ àkànṣe, kúrò láàárín agbègbè.

english: And then once you are confident that that can be done safely, you move to the next stage.
yoruba: Nígbà tó bá ti dáa yín lójú pé eyí ṣe é ṣe láìséwu, ẹ ó sì tẹ̀síwájú sí ipele tó kàn.

english: If you're not confident, you don't.
yoruba: Bí kò bá dáa yín lójú, ẹ ò ní ṣe bẹ́ẹ̀.

english: But step by step.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n ní ìpele-ìpele.

english: CA: And who would fund such experiments?
yoruba: CA: tani yóò ṣe onígbọ̀wọ́ irú ìdánwò bẹ́ẹ̀?

english: Because they kind of impact the whole planet at some level.
yoruba: Nítorí wọ́n nípa lára gbogbo àgbáyé ní àwọn ìpele kan.

english: Is that why nothing is happening on this?
yoruba: Ṣé ìdí nìyẹn tí nǹkankan ò ṣe tíì ṣẹlẹ̀ nípa eléyìí?

english: TK: So I think you can do small-scale experiments in national waters, and then it's probably the requirement of national funders to do that.
yoruba: TK: mo rò wí pé ẹ lè ṣe ìdánwò oníwọ̀n-kékeré nínú àwọn omi orílẹ̀-èdè, nígbà náà bóyá àwọn onígbọ̀wọ́ orílẹ̀-èdè nìkan ni yóò nílò láti ṣe ìyẹn.

english: But ultimately, if you wanted to counter ocean acidification in this way on a global scale, you would need to do it in international waters, and then you would need to have an international community working on it.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n nígbẹ́yìn, tí ẹ bá fẹ́ tako ẹ̀kan omi-òkun lórí ìwọ̀n àgbáyé lọ́nà yìí, ẹ máa nílò láti ṣe é nínú omi ilẹ̀ òkèèrè, ẹ ó sì nílò láti ní àwọn orílè-èdè àgbáyé láti ṣiṣẹ́ lórí rẹ̀.

english: CA: Even in national waters, you know, the ocean's all connected.
yoruba: CA: kódà nínú àwọn omi orílẹ̀-èdè, ẹ mọ̀, àwọn omi-òkun náà jápọ̀.

english: That lime is going to get out there.
yoruba: Ẹfun yẹn máa jáde síta yẹn.

english: And people feel outraged about doing experiments on the planet, as we've heard.
yoruba: Àwọn ènìyán sì máa ń bínú gan-an nípa ṣíṣe ìdánwò nínú ayé, bí a ṣe ti gbọ́.

english: How do you counter that?
yoruba: Báwo lẹ ó ṣe tako ìyẹn?

english: TK: I think you touch on something which is really important.
yoruba: TK: mo rò wí pé ẹ mẹ́nu ba nǹkankan tó ṣe pàtàkì púpọ̀

english: It's about a social license to operate.
yoruba: Nípa ìfàyègbà àwùjọ láti ṣiṣẹ́ ni.

english: And I think it may be that it is impossible to do, but we need to have the courage to try, to move this forward, to see what we can do, and to engage openly.
yoruba: Mo rò pé ó lè jẹ́ wí pé kò ṣe é ṣe láti ṣe é, ṣùgbọ́n a nílò láti ní ìgboyà láti gbìyànjú, láti sún èyí síwájú, láti rí nǹkan tí a lẹ̀ ṣe, ká sì sọ̀rọ̀ ní gbangba.

english: And we need to engage with people in a transparent way.
yoruba: A sì nílò láti bá àwọn ènìyàn sọ̀rọ̀ lọ́nà tó hàn kedere.

english: We need to ask them beforehand.
yoruba: A nílò láti bi wọ́n ṣíwájú.

english: And I think if we ask them, we have to be open to the possibility that the answer will come back, "No, don't do it.
yoruba: Mo sì rò wí pé tí a bá bi wọ́n, a ní láti ṣi ọkàn wa sílẹ̀ pé ó ṣe é ṣe kí ìdáhùn náà máa padà wá ní, “Rárá, má ṣe é.

english: CA: Thanks so much.
yoruba: CA: Ẹ ṣeun púpọ̀.

english: That was really fascinating.
yoruba: Ìyẹ́n fanimọ́ra gigi gan-an.

english: TK: Thank you.
yoruba: TK: Ẹ ṣeun.

english: A comprehensive, neighborhood-based response to COVID-19
yoruba: Ẹ̀kúnrẹ́rẹ́, ìdáhùn ajẹmọ́ agbègbè sí COVID-19.

english: Good evening.
yoruba: Ẹ káalẹ́.

english: It is such a blessing to work at the Harlem Children's Zone, an African-American-led organization that has pioneered the field of comprehensive place-based services, from cradle to career.
yoruba: Ìbùkún ni ó jẹ́ láti ṣiṣẹ́ ní Harlem Children’s Zone, ilé-iṣẹ́ tí àwọn Ọmọ Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ́ àti America ń léwájú t’ó ti ṣínà ẹ̀ka ẹ̀kúnrẹ́rẹ́ iṣẹ́ ajẹmọ́-àyè, láti ọmọ-ọwọ́ débi iṣẹ́.

english: And that word, "comprehensive," is so key to what we do.
yoruba: Ọ̀rọ̀ yẹn, “ẹ̀kúnrẹ́rẹ́” ṣe pàtàkì sí nǹkan tí à ń ṣe.

english: You know, most interventions focus on one piece of a complicated, giant puzzle.
yoruba: Ẹ mọ̀, ọ̀pọ̀ àwọn ìdásí máa ń kojú mọ́ ayò àmúdijú, ńlá kan ni.

english: But that's not enough to solve the puzzle.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n ìyẹn ò tó láti wá ìyanjú sí ayò náà.

english: You don't solve education without understanding the home context or the home environment of our young scholar.
yoruba: Ẹ ò lè yanjú ètò-ẹ̀kọ́ láìnímọ̀ nípa ọ̀gangan-ipò ilé tàbí ayíká ilé àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ kékèèké.

english: Or the broader context of health, nutrition or criminal justice.
yoruba: Tàbí ọ̀gangan-ipò ìlera tó fẹjú, ìṣaralóore tàbí ìdájọ́ ìwà-ọ̀daràn.

english: The unit of change for us is not the individual child, it's the entire neighborhood.
yoruba: Ìwọn àyípadà fún wa kì í ṣe ọmọ kọ̀ọ̀kan, gbogbo àdúgbò ni.

english: You have to do multiple things at the same time.
yoruba: Ẹ ní láti ṣe ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ nǹkan lẹ́ẹ̀kan náà.

english: And we have 20 years of data to prove that this works.
yoruba: A ní dátà ogún ọdún láti fi ṣẹ̀rí pé èyí ń ṣiṣé.

english: We've had 7,000 graduates of our baby college, we've eliminated the Black-white achievement gap in our schools.
yoruba: A ti ní ẹgbẹ̀rún méje àwọn àkẹ́kọ̀ọ́jáde ní ilé-ẹ̀kọ́ ìkókó wa, a ti pana àlàfo àṣeyọrí dúdú àti funfun ní ilé-ẹ̀kọ wa.

english: We've reduced obesity rates in our health programs and have close to 1,000 students enrolled in college.
yoruba: A ti mú àdínkù bá ìṣọwọ́-sanra nínú àwọn ètò ìlera wa sì ní tó ẹgbẹ̀rún kan àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ tí wọ́n ti forúkọsílẹ̀ ní ilé-ẹ̀kọ wa.

english: We weave together a net of services so tightly, so that no one will fall through the cracks.
yoruba: A hun àwọ̀n iṣẹ́ papọ̀ dọindọin, kí ẹnikẹ́ni má bá à jábọ́ níbi tó ti lanu.

english: And we've inspired global practitioners.
yoruba: A ti ṣe ìwúrí fún àwọn tó ń ṣe é lágbàáyé.

english: We've had over 500-plus communities across the US and 70-plus countries come and visit us to learn our model.
yoruba: A ti ní àwọn àwùjọ tó lé láàdọ́ta káàkiri orílẹ̀-ède US àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè tó lé láàdọ́rin ni wọ́n máa ń wá yọjú síwa láti kọ́ àwòṣe wa.

english: You see, the problems of the globe, and the problems of the world are not neatly siloed into buckets.
yoruba: Ṣẹ́ ẹ rí i, àwọn ìṣòro àgbáyé, àti àwọn ìṣòro ilé-ayé ni wọn ò bomi rin dáadáa.

english: So therefore the solutions must be comprehensive, they must be holistic.
yoruba: Nítorí náà àwọn ìyanjú náà gbọ́dọ̀ jẹ́ ẹ̀kúnrẹ́rẹ́, wọ́n gbọ́dọ̀ jẹ́ lápapọ̀.

english: And now we're in the midst of a global pandemic.
yoruba: Nísisìyí a wà nínú àjàkálẹ̀ àrùn káríayé.

english: COVID-19 has revealed to us what we always knew to be true.
yoruba: COVID-19 ti fi àwọn nǹkan ti a ti mọ̀ tẹ́lẹ̀ pé òótọ́ ni hàn wá.

english: The poorest among us pay the highest price with their lives and their livelihood.
yoruba: Àwọn tí wọ́n kúṣẹ̀ jùlọ láàárín wa ni wọ́n ń san ẹ̀jẹ́ tó pọ̀jù pẹ̀lú èmi wọn àti ọ̀nà ìwá ìjẹ-ìmu wọn.

english: And that's playing out every day in the African American community, where we're 3.6 times more likely to die of COVID than our white counterparts.
yoruba: Ìyẹ́n sì ń ṣẹlẹ̀ lójoojúmọ́ ní àwùjọ àwọn ọmọ ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ ní orílẹ̀-ède America, níbi tó ti ṣe é ṣe kí COVID pa wa ní ìlọ́po mẹ́rìn-dín-lọ́gbọ̀n ju àwọn akẹgbẹ́ wa tí wọ́n jẹ́ aláwò funfun lọ.

english: We're seeing those health disparities on the ground in New York City, our nation's epicenter.
yoruba: À ń rí àwọn ìyàtọ̀ ìlera wọ̀nyẹn lọ́pọ̀lọpọ̀ ní New York City, níbi tó ti àrùn yìí ti wọ́pọ̀ jùlọ lórílẹ̀-ède wa.

english: And to compound the impact of the health disparities, there's significant economic devastation, where one in four of our families in Harlem report food insecurity, and 57 percent report a loss of income or a loss of their job.
yoruba: Láti sọ ipa ìyàtọ̀ ìlera náà di púpọ̀, ìpalára ọrọ̀ ajé tó fojú hàn wà, níbi tí ọ̀kan nínú mẹ́rin àwọn ẹbíi wa ní Harlem ti ń jábọ̀ àìróúnjẹ jẹ, ti ìda mẹ́tà-dín-lọ́gọ́ta ń jábọ̀ ìpàdánù owó-oṣù tàbí ìpàdánù iṣẹ́ wọn.

english: But to better understand the work of the Harlem Children's Zone, I want to share a story with you, about a second-grade scholar named Sean.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n láti túbọ̀ ní ìmọ̀ nípa iṣẹ́ tí Harlem Children Zone ń ṣe, mo fẹ́ sọ ìtàn kan fún yín, nípa akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ilé-ìwé alákọ̀ọ́bẹ́rẹ̀ kejì tí orúkọ rẹ̀ ńjẹ́ Sean.

english: Sean is a beautiful Black boy whose smile would light up any room that he's in.
yoruba: Sean jẹ́ ọmọdékùnrin aláwọ̀-dúdú to rewà tí ẹ̀rin rẹ̀ máa ń mú ìdùnnú wọ inú yàrá tó bá wà ni.

english: And when quarantine began in March, we noticed that Sean wasn't attending virtual school.
yoruba: Nígbà tí ìyàsọ́tọ̀ bẹ́rẹ̀ ní oṣù Ẹ̀rẹnà, a ṣàkíyèsí wí pé Sean ò kín wá sí ilé-ẹ̀kọ́ orí ẹ̀rọ ayélukára.

english: And after some investigation, we've come to learn that Sean's mom was hospitalized due to COVID.
yoruba: Léyìn ìwádìí díẹ̀, a wá mọ̀ wí pé ìya Sean wà nílé-ìwòsàn nítorí COVID.

english: So he was at home with grandma and his baby sibling, who was his only viable support system, since Sean's father is incarcerated.
yoruba: Òún wà nílé pẹ̀lu ìyá-àgba rẹ̀ àti àbúro rẹ̀ kékeré, tó ṣe pé òun nìkan náà ni alátìlẹyìn fun, nígbà tó jẹ́ wí pé wọ́n ti fi baba Sean sẹ́wọ̀n.

english: Grandma was struggling.
yoruba: Ìyá-àgbà ń tiraka ni.

english: There wasn't much food in the household, limited diapers, and Sean didn't even have a computer.
yoruba: Kò sí oúnjẹ púpọ̀ ní ilé náà, ìlédì díẹ̀, Sean náà ò wulẹ̀ ní ẹ̀rọ-ayárabíàṣá kankan.

english: When mom was released from the hospital, their challenges deepened, because they could no longer stay with grandma, due to her preexisting health conditions.
yoruba: Nígbà tí wọ́n tú ìya rẹ̀ sílẹ̀ nílé-ìwòsàn, ìdojúko wọ́n túbọ̀ fẹjú síi, nítorí wọn ò lè gbépọ̀ pẹ̀lú ìyá-àgba wọn mọ́, nítorí ipọ̀-ilere àtẹ̀yìnwá rẹ̀.

english: So Sean, his baby sibling and his mom had to go to a shelter.
yoruba: Nitorí náà Sean, àbúro rẹ̀ kékeré àti ìya rẹ̀ ní láti lọ sílé àwọn aláìní.

english: Sean's story is not atypical at the Harlem Children's Zone.
yoruba: Ìtan Sean kìí ṣe ní Harlem Children’s Zone nìkan.

english: We know Sean and millions like him all across the country deserve to have everything that this world has to offer, without inequality robbing them of that opportunity.
